General Remarks

Here is the complete documentation for 84000 TEI Documents. In the body there is a list of all the specifications for element, model classes, attribute classes, macros, and datatypes. The back matter contains first a set of guidelines for our own markup editors showing the process for the markup stage of our texts, which is then followed by some other appendices with further topeics and instructions for markup editors. All of these sections are accessible through links in the table of contents.

NOTE FOR UPDATING THE SCHEMA: This ODD contains some content models that are written directly with RELAX NG in order to shape and restrict the form for published 84000 texts. If these need to be updated in the ODD, these content models, which outline the whole of the <text> are primarily to be found in the <elementSpec>s for the <teiHeader>, <front>, <body>, and <back> elementsSome RELAX NG content models are also defined in the a few <macroSpec> elements that are pointed to from within the content models of these four mentioned <elementSpec>s. All the the <macroSpec>s have been placed at the beginning of the ODD's XML after the <moduleRef>s and <classSpec>s, these are then followed by the <elementSpec>s. See Appendix I for more details on proceedures for updating the schema.

1. Elements

1.1. <TEI>

<TEI> (TEI document) contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resourceLike class. Multiple <TEI> elements may be combined to form a <teiCorpus> element. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module textstructure
Attributes Attributes
version specifies the version number of the TEI Guidelines against which this document is valid.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.version
Note

Major editions of the Guidelines have long been informally referred to by a name made up of the letter P (for Proposal) followed by a digit. The current release is one of the many releases of the fifth major edition of the Guidelines, known as P5. This attribute may be used to associate a TEI document with a specific release of the P5 Guidelines, in the absence of a more precise association provided by the source attribute on the associated <schemaSpec>.
Contained by
—
May contain
header: teiHeader
textstructure: text
Note

This element is required. It is customary to specify the TEI namespace http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0 on it, using the xmlns attribute.
Example The following example is a map for an 84000 TEI document
<TEI xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">  <teiHeader>   <fileDesc>    <titleStmt/>    <editionStmt/>    <publicationStmt/>    <sourceDesc/>    <notesStmt/>   </fileDesc>  </teiHeader>  <text>   <front>    <div type="summary"/>    <div type="acknowledgment"/>    <div type="introduction">     <div type="section"/>     <div type="section"/>     <div type="section"/> <!--... etc.-->    </div>   </front>   <body>    <div type="translation">     <div type="chapter"/>     <div type="chapter"/>     <div type="chapter"/> <!--...-->     <div type="colophon"/>    </div>   </body>   <back>    <div type="notes"/>    <div type="listBibl"/>    <div type="glossary"/>   </back>  </text> </TEI>
Schematron
<s:ns prefix="tei"  uri="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"/> <s:ns prefix="xs"  uri="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"/>
Schematron
<s:ns prefix="rng"  uri="http://relaxng.org/ns/structure/1.0"/>
Content model 
<content>
 <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
  <elementRef key="teiHeader"/>
  <classRef key="model.resourceLike"
   maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
 </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element TEI { attribute version { text }?, ( teiHeader, model.resourceLike+ ) }

1.2. <abbr>

<abbr> (abbreviation) contains an abbreviation of any sort. [3.5.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions]
Module core
Member of
model.pPart.editorial
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: hi
character data
Note

For 84000 documents, this element is only used to identify abbreviations in the list of abbreviations within the "Notes" section in the <back>. In this section it should be followed by a <expan> element showing the expanded form of the abbreviation. This element should not be used as the abbreviations appear in the body of the text.
Example
<back>  <div type="notes">   <head type="notes">Notes</head>   <list type="abbreviations">    <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-471">     <abbr>Ch.</abbr>     <expan>Chinese</expan>    </item>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-472">     <abbr>X</abbr>     <expan>Xuanzang’s Ch. translation</expan>    </item>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-473">     <abbr>K</abbr>     <expan>Kumārajīva’s Ch. translation</expan>    </item>   </list>  </div> <!--...--> </back>
Content model 
<content/>
Schema Declaration 
element abbr { ( text | hi )+ }

1.3. <author>

<author> in a bibliographic reference, contains the name(s) of an author, personal or corporate, of a work; for example in the same form as that provided by a recognized bibliographic name authority. [3.11.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
role Describes the author's role in the translation of the text. "translatorMain" and "translatorEng" denote the Tibetan to English translators of the current 84000 text while the "translatorTib" denotes the Tibetan translator of the the Kangyur source.
Status Required
Legal values are:
translatorMain
translatorEng
translatorTib
preface
Member of
model.respLike
Contained by
core: bibl
header: editionStmt titleStmt
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic lb milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

In the case of the 84000 texts, the author element appears in the title statement, <titleStmt>, to identify the translator of the published text, and in the source description, <sourceDesc>, to identify the translator(s) of the source text. The former deals with those responsible for the English translation and the latter lists those who translated the text into Tibetan.
Example
<titleStmt>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’da’ ka ye shes kyi mdo</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">འདའ་ཀ་ཡེ་ཤེས་ཀྱི་མདོ།</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Sūtra on Wisdom at the Hour of    Death</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Atyaya­jñāna­sūtra</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་འདའ་ཀ་ཡེ་ཤེས་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa ’da’ ka ye shes zhes bya ba theg    pa chen po’i mdo</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “Wisdom at the Hour    of Death”</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Āryātyaya­jñāna­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>  <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>  <author ref="contributors.xml#person-115"   role="translatorMain">Translated by Tom Tillemans’ class in the    University of Vienna’s program of Buddhist Translation Studies<lb/> under the    patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.</author>  <author ref="contributors.xml#person-116"   role="translatorEng"/> </titleStmt>
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl>   <ref>Toh 176 </ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur vol. 60 (mdo sde, ma), folios 175.a–239.a </biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Chönyi Tsultrim</author>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element author
{
   attribute role
   {
      "translatorMain" | "translatorEng" | "translatorTib" | "preface"
   },
   macro.phraseSeq
}

1.4. <availability>

<availability> supplies information about the availability of a text, for example any restrictions on its use or distribution, its copyright status, any licence applying to it, etc. [2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc.]
Module header
Contained by
—
May contain
header: licence
Note

<availability> element appears as part of the <publicationStmt> which is part of the <teiHeader> in every text.
Example For 84000 texts the <availability> element should always appear as follows:
<availability>  <licence>   <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>   <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND      (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be copied      or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for commercial      advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the Creative Commons      license.</p>  </licence> </availability>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="licence"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element availability { licence }

1.5. <back>

<back> (back matter) <back> (back matter) is a default <text> structure, contains any appendixes, etc. following the main part of a text, the <body>. [4.7. Back Matter 4. Default Text Structure]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: text
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
textstructure: trailer
character data
Note

In the 84000 TEI specification the back structure contains the notes, bibliography and the glossary, in that order.
Example
<back>  <div type="notes">   <head type="notes">Notes</head>   <list type="abbreviations">    <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-471">     <abbr>Ch.</abbr>     <expan>Chinese</expan>    </item>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-472">     <abbr>X</abbr>     <expan>Xuanzang’s Ch. translation</expan>    </item> <!--...-->   </list>  </div>  <div type="listBibl">   <head type="listBibl">Bibliography</head>   <div type="section">    <head type="section">Tibetan and Sanskrit sources</head>    <bibl xml:id="UT22084-060-005-474">     <title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa dri ma med par grags pas bstan pa zhes bya          ba theg pa chen po’i mdo </title> (<title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­vimala­kīrti­nirdeśa­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>). Toh. 176, Degé        Kangyur, vol. 60 (mdo sde, ma), folios 175b–239a. </bibl>    <bibl xml:id="UT22084-060-005-476"> Study Group on Buddhist Sanskrit Literature.        梵文維摩經 : ポタラ宮所蔵写本に基づく校訂. <title xml:lang="en">Vimalakīrtinirdeśa, A Sanskrit          Edition Based upon the Manuscript Newly Found at the Potala Palace</title>.        Tokyo: Institute for Comprehensive Studies of Buddhism, Taishō Daigaku        Shuppankai, 2006. </bibl> <!--...-->   </div> <!--...-->  </div>  <div type="glossary">   <list type="glossary">    <item>     <gloss type="term"      xml:id="UT22084-060-005-498">      <term>Abhidharma</term>      <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">chos mngon pa </term>      <term xml:lang="bo">ཆོས་མངོན་པ།</term>      <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Abhidharma</term>      <term type="definition">Conventionally, the general name for the Buddhist            teachings presented in a scientific manner, as a fully elaborated            transcendental psychology. </term>     </gloss>    </item> <!--...-->   </list>  </div> </back>
Content model 
<content>notesnotesabbreviationsabbreviationslistBibllistBiblsectionsectionsectionsectionglossaryglossarytermpersonplacetextmarkedmatchenBo-LtnboSa-LtnPi-LtnzhZh-LtndefinitionalternativeappendixappendixtitleMainprologueprologue</content>
Schema Declaration 
element back
{
   (
      element div
      {
         attribute type { "notes" },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "notes" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         }?,
         element list
         {
            attribute type { "abbreviations" },
            element head
            {
               attribute type { "abbreviations" },
               attribute tid { text }?,
               string
            },
            element item
            {
               attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
               text,
               abbr?,
               element expan { ( foreign* | title* | ptr* | text )+ }?
            }+
         }?
      }?
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "listBibl" },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "listBibl" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         },
         element div
         {
            attribute type { "section" },
            (
               element head
               {
                  attribute type { "section" },
                  attribute tid { text }?,
                  text
               }?
             | p*
             | hi*
             | lb*
             | element bibl
               {
                  attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
                  (
                     title*
                   | foreign*
                   | lb*
                   | ptr*
                   | ref*
                   | hi*
                   | element author { string }*
                   | element date { string }*
                   | text
                  )+
               }*
             | element div
               {
                  attribute type { "section" },
                  (
                     element head
                     {
                        attribute type { "section" },
                        attribute tid { text }?,
                        text
                     }?
                   | lb*
                   | element bibl
                     {
                        attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id
                        {
                           xsd:ID
                        },
                        (
                           title*
                         | foreign*
                         | lb*
                         | ptr*
                         | ref*
                         | hi*
                         | element author { string }*
                         | element date { string }*
                         | text
                        )+
                     }*
                  )+
               }*
            )+
         }*
      }
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "glossary" },
         element list
         {
            attribute type { "glossary" },
            element item
            {
               element gloss
               {
                  attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
                  attribute type { "term" | "person" | "place" | "text" },
                  attribute mode { "marked" | "match" }?,
                  element term
                  {
                     (
                        text
                      | term*
                      | foreign*
                      | title*
                      | emph*
                      | ptr*
                      | ref*
                      | hi*
                     )+,
                     attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]lang
                     {
                        "en"
                      | "Bo-Ltn"
                      | "bo"
                      | "Sa-Ltn"
                      | "Pi-Ltn"
                      | "zh"
                      | "Zh-Ltn"
                     }?,
                     attribute type { "definition" | "alternative" }?
                  }+
               }?
            }+
         }?
      }
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "appendix" },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "appendix" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "titleMain" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         }?,
         element div
         {
            attribute type { "prologue" },
            element head
            {
               attribute type { "prologue" },
               attribute tid { text }?,
               text
            },
            (
               milestone*
             | paragraph*
             | q*
             | lg*
             | lb*
             | trailer*
             | list*
             | element label { string }*
             | translation-section*
            )+
         }*,
         translation-section*,
         translation-chapter*
      }?
   )+
}

1.6. <bibl>

<bibl> (bibliographic citation) contains a loosely-structured bibliographic citation of which the sub-components may or may not be explicitly tagged. [3.11.1. Methods of Encoding Bibliographic References and Lists of References 2.2.7. The Source Description 15.3.2. Declarable Elements]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id)
type characterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
key
Status Optional
Member of
model.biblLike model.biblPart
Contained by
core: bibl item l note p q ref title
header: publicationStmt sourceDesc
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr author bibl biblScope date distinct editor emph expan foreign gloss lb milestone name note ptr publisher ref term title
header: edition idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

For 84000 texts, the <bibl> element is used for each bibliographic entry in the bibliography within the <back> section of the text. However, in each 84000 text the <bibl> element is also used once in the <sourceDesc> to describe the bibliographic information for the 84000 text itelf; in this case the <bibl> is more elaborate and contains several child elements, see the second example below:
Example
<bibl xml:id="UT22084-060-005-486">Bagchi, S. (ed.). <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn"> Guhya­samāja­tantra</title>. Buddhist Sanskrit Texts, No. 9. Darbhanga: Mithila Institute of Postgraduate Studies and Research in Sanskrit Learning, 1965. </bibl>
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh83" type="text">   <ref>Toh 83</ref>, <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios      71.a–94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Degé Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a–94a</citedRange-->   <author role="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author>   <author role="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author>   <author role="translatorTib">Yeshé Dé</author>   <location count-pages="48">    <start page="143" volume="44"/>    <end page="190" volume="44"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <textNode/>
  <classRef key="model.gLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.highlighted"/>
  <classRef key="model.pPart.data"/>
  <classRef key="model.pPart.edit"/>
  <classRef key="model.segLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.ptrLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.biblPart"/>
  <classRef key="model.global"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element bibl
{

1.8. <body>

<body> (text body) contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter. [4. Default Text Structure]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: text
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
textstructure: trailer
character data
Note

<body> (text body) contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter. So in an 84000 TEI encoded document, the body contains the whole translated text. It does not material written by the translator or editors, but just the original text in translation. It is part of the <text>, coming after <front> and before <back>. The body section opens approximately the same way in every document. The front closing tag precedes the body opening tag. That is followed by the div tag with the type attribute containing the "translation" value. This is followed by the head elements, with type values first of "translation" and then "titleMain", and then "titleHon" as shown below. After this comes the chapter or section div's, and so on. Even if there is no chapter division in the body of the translated text, there is minimally one section or chapter div, containing then the whole of the translation, and closing before the "colophon". Structurally the colophon section is equivalent to a chapter, and colophon is a value of a type attribute of a div element. The colophon div closes and then comes the closing div tag of the translation, and then the closing body tag.
Example
<body>  <div type="translation">   <head type="translation">The Translation</head>   <head type="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra</head>   <head type="titleMain">The Inquiry of Jayamati</head>   <div type="section">    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-061-014-13"/>    <p tid="15">     <ref cRef="F.250.b"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisatvas! </p>    <lb/>    <p tid="16">Thus I have heard at one time. The Bhagavān was residing at the        grove of Anāthapiṇḍada in Jeta Wood in Śrāvastī together with a great assembly        of monks and a great multitude of bodhisatvas. Then, the Bhagavān addressed        the bodhisatva Jayamati as follows. </p>    <lb/> <!--...-->   </div>   <div type="colophon">    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-061-014-16"/>    <p tid="19">This completes the Noble Mahāyāna sūtra, <title xml:lang="en">The          Inquiry of Jayamati</title>.</p>   </div>  </div> </body>
Content model 
<content>translationtranslationtitleHontitleMainprologueprologuecolophoncolophon</content>

            milestone*

          | q*
          | lb*
          | lg*
          | trailer*
          | list*

          | list*
          | element label { string }*

         )+
      }*
   }?
}

1.11. <distinct>

<distinct> identifies any word or phrase which is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage. [3.3.2.3. Other Linguistically Distinct Material]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type specifies the sublanguage or register to which the word or phrase is being assigned
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Member of
model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic lb milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

For 84000 texts, our parser italicizes text within this element. In the mark-up process, text that should be italicized but does not fall into the category of foreign text (tagged with the <foreign> element) should be marked up either with the <distinct> or <emph> element. <distinct> indicates that the italics identify any word or phrase that is not foreign, but is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage. <emph> indicates that the italicized words are not in a foreign language but are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect.
Example
<p tid="115"> “It is as follows: Mañjuśrī, in the great ocean there is a great, precious jewel called <distinct>Fulfilling All Wishes</distinct>. <!--...--> </p>
Example
<p> <!--...--> According to the CMT, this awakening is irreversible and is therefore termed <distinct>indestructible awakening</distinct> (<foreign type="term" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">vajrabodhi</foreign>). <!--...--> </p>

1.12. <div>

<div> (text division) contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text. [4.1. Divisions of the Body]
Module textstructure
Attributes Attributes
type These are the divs for 84000 translations - used in the front, body or back.
Derived from att.typed
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
chapter
summary
introduction
acknowledgment
listBibl
section
translation
chapter
section
colophon
notes
glossary
prologue
preface
Member of
model.divLike
Contained by
textstructure: div
May contain
core: bibl head l label lb lg list milestone note p q
textstructure: div trailer
Note

<div> (text division) contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text. All three subsections of the Front are designated by a div tag, which includes a type attribute that holds a value reflecting which subsection it is, for example: <div type="acknowledgment">. Likewise the body has a div tag marking the translation, and within the translation, at least two div's, making the main part of the translation and the colophon. Any further subdivisions of the translation, into chapters or sections require additional div tags. All of the tags also contain the type attribute and translation, chapter, section or colophon values. This works the same way for the back section, with four div tags, at least. Each again has the type attribute and values of notes, listBibl (within listBible at least one div with type section) and glossary.

Note that a prologue should have type="prologue" and not be labeled as "section".

The following is the <div> structure of 22084-089-001, Toh 544. It shows only and all of the div tags in the "text", since there are no div tags in the teiHeader. <text>

Example
<text>  <front>   <div type="summary"/>   <div type="acknowledgment"/>   <div type="introduction">    <div type="section"/>    <div type="section"/>    <div type="section"/>   </div>  </front>  <body>   <div type="translation">    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="chapter"/>   </div>  </body>  <back>   <div type="notes"/>   <div type="listBibl">    <div type="section"/>   </div>   <div type="glossary"/>  </back> </text>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:l"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div. </s:report>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:p or ancestor::tei:ab and not(ancestor::tei:floatingText)"> Abstract model violation: p and ab may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div. </s:report>

1.13. <edition>

<edition> describes the particularities of one edition of a text. [2.2.2. The Edition Statement]
Module header
Member of
model.biblPart
Contained by
core: bibl
header: editionStmt
May contain
core: date
character data
Note

Because of the particularities of electronic publishing, P5 Guidelines says that "the term edition may be used for a particular state of a machine-readable text at which substantive changes are made and fixed. The words revision and update, by contrast, are used for minor changes to a file which do not amount to a new edition. No simple rule can specify how ‘substantive’ changes have to be before they are regarded as producing a new edition, rather than a simple update. The general principle proposed here is that the production of a new edition entails a significant change in the intellectual content of the file, rather than its encoding or appearance. " For 84000 texts, the element should include a version number or name and can include the <date> element.
Example
<edition>v 1.0 <date>2016</date> </edition>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
 <elementRef key="date" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element edition { text, date? }

1.14. <editionStmt>

<editionStmt> (edition statement) groups information relating to one edition of a text. [2.2.2. The Edition Statement 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc teiHeader
May contain
core: author editor p
header: edition
Note

According to the TEI P5 Guidelines, <editionStmt> (edition statement) is the second component of the fileDesc element and groups information relating to one edition of a text. It is an optional element, but recommended. It follows directly after the </titleStmt>, and proceeds the <publicationStmt>. There are 5 potential child elements that it can contain, but for 84000 texts, the only child element is the <edition> tag, and that element contains in turn the <date> element, the grandchild of the <editionStmt> element.
Example
<editionStmt>  <edition>v 1.0 <date>2016</date>  </edition> </editionStmt>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
  <classRef key="model.pLike"
   maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
  <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
   <elementRef key="edition"/>
   <classRef key="model.respLike"
    maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
  </sequence>
 </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element editionStmt { model.pLike+ | ( edition, model.respLike* ) }

1.16. <emph>

<emph> (emphasized) marks words or phrases which are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect. [3.3.2.2. Emphatic Words and Phrases 3.3.2. Emphasis, Foreign Words, and Unusual Language]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
rend
Status Optional
Sample values include
bold
Member of
model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: term
character data
Note

For 84000 texts, our parser italicizes text within this element. In the mark-up process, text that should be italicized but does not fall into the category of foreign text (tagged with the <foreign> element) should be marked up either with the <distinct> or <emph> element. <distinct> indicates that the italics identify any word or phrase that is not foreign, but is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage. <emph> indicates that the italicized words are not in a foreign language but are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect.

<emph> is also used for the word "Warning" in the tantric restriction within the <availability> element, and here it should be given the rend with the value "bold" inorder to render it bold as such.
Example
<note> <!--...--> It should be remembered here that “destructible” = the relative, and “indestructible” = the absolute. Thus, Pratyakṣa­darśa is affirming that the superficial <emph>is</emph> the ultimate, etc. <!--...--> </note>
Example
<availability>  <p type="tantricRestriction">   <emph rend="bold">Warning:</emph> Readers are reminded that according to Vajrayāna    Buddhist tradition there are restrictions and commitments concerning tantra.    Practitioners who are not sure if they should read this translation are advised to    consult the authorities of their lineage. The responsibility for reading this text    or sharing it with others who may or may not fulfill the requirements lies in the    hands of readers.</p> <!--...--> </availability>

1.19. <fileDesc>

<fileDesc> (file description) contains a full bibliographic description of an electronic file. [2.2. The File Description 2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components]

—

Note

The major source of information for those seeking to create a catalogue entry or bibliographic citation for an electronic file. As such, it provides a title and statements of responsibility together with details of the publication or distribution of the file, of any series to which it belongs, and detailed bibliographic notes for matters not addressed elsewhere in the header. It also contains a full bibliographic description for the source or sources from which the electronic text was derived.
Note

Currently, in 84000 texts the <fileDesc> contains the following elements in this order: a title statement (<titleStmt>), a edition statement (<editionStmt>), a publication statement (<publicationStmt>), a source description (<sourceDesc>), and a notes statement (<notesStmt>). Note that in 84000 specifications the placement of the <sourceDesc> and <notesStmt> are switched from that in the standard TEI header module, in which the <notesStmt> comes before the <sourceDesc>

Example
<fileDesc>  <titleStmt>   <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་རྒྱལ་པོའི་མདོ།</title> <!--... etc. a list of all the titles and authors-->  </titleStmt>  <editionStmt>   <edition>v 1.3 <date>2017</date>   </edition>  </editionStmt>  <publicationStmt status="1">   <publisher>    <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit      initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern      languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>   <availability>    <licence>     <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>     <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC          BY-NC-ND (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It          may be copied or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and          not for commercial advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see          the Creative Commons license.</p>    </licence>   </availability>   <idno xml:id="UT22084-044-003"/>   <note>An early mistake in the assigning of UT numbers within the 84000 project      means that these ids diverge slightly from the standard logic.</note>   <date>2017-02-25</date>  </publicationStmt>  <sourceDesc>   <bibl key="toh83" type="text">    <ref>Toh 83</ref>, <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios        71.a–94.b</biblScope>    <author role="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author>    <author role="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author>    <author role="translatorTib">Yeshé Dé</author>    <location count-pages="48">     <start page="143" volume="44"/>     <end page="190" volume="44"/>    </location>    <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/>   </bibl>  </sourceDesc>  <notesStmt>   <note date-time="2019-02-26T08:34:43.421Z"    type="lastUpdated" user="celso">26/02/2019 08:34:43</note>  </notesStmt> </fileDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
  <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
   <elementRef key="titleStmt"/>
   <elementRef key="editionStmt"
    minOccurs="0"/>
   <elementRef key="extent" minOccurs="0"/>
   <elementRef key="publicationStmt"/>
   <elementRef key="seriesStmt"
    minOccurs="0"/>
   <elementRef key="notesStmt"
    minOccurs="0"/>
  </sequence>
  <elementRef key="sourceDesc"
   maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
 </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration

{
   (
      titleStmt,
      editionStmt?,

      publicationStmt,

   ),
   sourceDesc+
}

1.20. <foreign>

<foreign> identifies a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than that of the surrounding text. [3.3.2.1. Foreign Words or Expressions]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:lang
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan transcribed in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti transcribed in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi transcribed in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese transcribed in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada transcribed in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi transcribed in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali transcribed in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit transcribed in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit transcribed in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil transcribed in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai transcribed in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese transcribed in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic transcribed in Roman script.
type Identifies a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than that of the surrounding text. Denotes also that the word or phrase in question will appear in italics. The full tag includes the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate language value and also the type attribute with term, quote, or mantra as a value.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
quote
Any untranslated quotations taken from the source text (the translator will typically put these in the endnotes).
“Reverend Ānanda, do not bring shame upon us, but go in silence, lest the outsider sectarians should hear your words.” (Endnote−Tib. <foreign type="quote"  xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzhan mu stegs can spyod pa pa dang kun tu rgyu dang gcer bu pa dang tsho ba pa dag</foreign>; Skt. <foreign type="quote"  xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">anyatīrthika caraka parivrajaka nigranthājīvāḥ</foreign>. I have simply rendered this “outsider sectarians” so as not to burden the reader with irrelevant names, as this expression is a cliché for all the outsider groups occurring in other sūtras.)
mantra
Any mantras or seed syllables corresponding to the language used.
Then the Blessed One resolutely spoke his root mantra, the statement of all activity: “<foreign type="mantra"  xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Oṃ nīlāmbaradharavajrapāṇi hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ</foreign>.”
term
A foreign term in parenthesis following its translation or a relatively rare foreign term left un-translated. Foreign terms also include short phrases that constitute technical or commonly used terms.
The mind is immaterial, invisible, baseless, and unconscious (Tib. <foreign type="term"  xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">rnam par rig pa med pa</foreign>; Skt. <foreign type="Sa-Ltn"  xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">avijñapti</foreign>; lit. “without means of cognition”).
Note

Sometimes there may be some gray areas between what constitutes a "term" and what constitutes a "quote" in this situation the mark-up editor should use their own judgment to determine the value, keeping in mind which category would be more useful for researchers making a hypothetical search through the text.
Member of
model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic lb milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

84000 uses this element to tag foreign words throughout documents with exception for the titles of texts, which should be tagged with the <title> element. All instances of the <foreign> element must contain the xml:lang with its value following the ISO 639-1 codes; however, for any language that is not usually written in a Roman script (i.e., Sanskrit, Tibetan, Chinese, Pali, etc...), if the language is written in a Romanized script then the first letter should be capitalized and "-Ltn" should be added to the value. For example Sanskrit "sa" becomes "Sa-Ltn", Tibetan "bo" becomes "Bo-Ltn", Chinese "zh" becomes "Zh-Ltn" and so forth. But use, the regular ISO 639-1 code if the native script is used (usually this should only be the case with Tibetan "bo" or Chinese "zh"). Most instances of the <foreign> element should include the type attribute detailed above, although there are a few exceptions when foreign text will not fall into the "term", "quote", or "mantra" category and this attribute is not needed, for instance, the case of Tibetan Wylie transliteration given in parenthesis after the phonetic rendering of a Tibetan name. However, in general romanized foreign names should not be tagged with the <foreign> element. This tag should only be used for foreign text that are to be italicized according to 84000's style guidelines, as our parser will italicize all instances of foreign text in the web display. There is one exception to this, in that text in the Tibetan and Chinese script should be tagged with the <foreign> element, but will not be italicized in the parser.
Example
<note>With this paragraph begins a list of the “four confidences (<foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">vaiśāradya</foreign>) of a thus-gone one.”</note>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>

    | "Kn-Ltn"
    | "Mr-Ltn"

    | "Pra-Ltn"
    | "Sa-Ltn"
    | "Ta-Ltn"
    | "Th-Ltn"
    | "Zh-Ltn"
    | "bo"
    | "de"
    | "el"
    | "en"
    | "fr"
    | "it"
    | "la"
    | "zh"
    | "middle_indic-Ltn"
   },

   macro.phraseSeq
}

1.21. <front>

<front> (front matter) contains any prefatory matter (headers, abstracts, title page, prefaces, dedications, etc.) found at the start of a document, before the main body. [4.6. Title Pages 4. Default Text Structure]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: text
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
textstructure: trailer
character data
Note

The <front> (front matter) contains any prefatory matter. It is the first section of the <text> structure, so it comes after the <teiHeader>, which is outside of the <text> itself, and before the <body>, which is the second part of the <text> proper. The front matter of an encoded text should not be confused with the TEI header. The TEI Header, serves as a kind of front matter for the computer file itself, not the text it encodes. The <front> contains the written material that does not form part of the translated text, including the summary, acknowledgement and introduction (in that order). These three sections in the <front> are nested within <div> elements which each are appropriately labeled by the value of their type attribute, as in the following example:
Example
<front>  <div type="summary">   <head type="summary">Summary</head>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-046-001-1"/>   <p tid="1"> <!--...-->   </p>  </div>  <div type="acknowledgment">   <head type="acknowledgment"> Acknowledgments</head>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-046-001-2"/>   <p tid="2"> <!--...-->   </p>   <p tid="3"> <!--...-->   </p>  </div>  <div type="introduction">   <head type="introduction">Introduction</head>   <div type="section">    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-046-001-3"/>    <p tid="7"> <!--...-->    </p>   </div>  </div> </front>
Content model 
<content>summarysummaryacknowledgmentacknowledgmentprefaceprefaceintroductionintroductionsectionsection</content>
Schema Declaration 
element front
{
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "summary" },
      (
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "summary" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         }
       | milestone*
       | paragraph*
       | lg*
      )+
   }?,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "acknowledgment" },
      (
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "acknowledgment" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         }
       | milestone*
       | paragraph*
       | lg*
      )+
   }?,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "preface" },
      element head
      {
         attribute type { "preface" },
         attribute tid { text }?,
         text
      },
      (
         milestone*
       | paragraph*
       | q*
       | lb*
       | lg*
       | trailer*
       | list*
       | element label { string }*
       | translation-section*
      )+
   }*,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "introduction" },
      (
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "introduction" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            text
         }
       | milestone*
       | paragraph*
       | ptr*
       | lg*
       | lb*
       | element div
         {
            attribute type { "section" },
            (
               element head
               {
                  attribute type { "section" },
                  attribute tid { text }?,
                  text
               }?
             | milestone*
             | paragraph*
             | q*
             | lg*
             | lb*
             | list*
            )+
         }*
      )+
   }?
}

1.22. <gloss>

<gloss> identifies a phrase or word used to provide a gloss or definition for some other word or phrase. [3.3.4. Terms, Glosses, Equivalents, and Descriptions 22.4.1. Description of Components]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Datatype ID
type Identifies the glossary item as being either a person, place, or term.
Derived from att.typed
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
person
place
term
text
mode Used to identify terms in the glossary that may not be applicable to every instance in the text. A <gloss> element with the mode "match" will match with all instances of that string in the text unless they are marked with <term type="ignore">. A term in the glossary with the mode "marked" will only link to terms with the <term> element.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
match
marked
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: term
Note

In the glossary found in the back material of each 84000 text, the <gloss> element wraps each glossary term with its variations in Tibetan and Sanskrit along with a definition. The <gloss> element is requires the xml:id attribute, and the type attribute declaring whether it is a "term", "person", "place", or "text". The first <term> element (which has no attributes and presents the English translation of the term) will create a link to the glossary in the reading room for each instance of that term as it appears as a string in the text. However, in some cases it may be inappropriate to link certain strings of text that match this term and so optionally the mode attribute may be added with the values of "marked" or "match". A <gloss> element with the mode "match" will match with all instances of that string in the text unless they are marked with <term type="ignore">. A term in the glossary with the mode "marked" will only link to terms with the <term> element. of the term, that are marked also by <term> tags the type attribute with the value of "alternate".
Note

There also may be occasions were the translator has used alternate translations for the same term, or different variations for the spelling of a string that correspond to the same glossary entry. In this case an additional <term > element should be added with the value "alternative". This will cause the parser to link these alternate string instances of the text in 84000's reading room.
Example
<gloss mode="marked" type="place"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4817">  <term>Mucilinda </term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">btang bzung </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">བཏང་བཟུང།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Mucilinda</term>  <term type="definition">An unidentified mountain mentioned in a number of sūtras,    not apparently connected to the well-known nāga of that name, but perhaps to the    sacred mucilinda tree, known in English mainly as the bayur tree.</term> </gloss>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="term"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element gloss
{
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute xml:id { text },
   attribute type { "person" | "place" | "term" | "text" },
   attribute mode { "match" | "marked" }?,
   term+
}

1.24. <head>

<head> (heading) contains any type of heading, for example the title of a section, or the heading of a list, glossary, manuscript description, etc. [4.2.1. Headings and Trailers]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type classifies the head according to the 84000 typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
summary
introduction
appendix
acknowledgment
abbreviations
translation

Status Optional
Member of
model.headLike

core: list

Note

Unlike the div tags, the text between the opening and closing head tags are visible to the reader. So any major section of the front, body or back parts of the text that has a title, wraps that title in a head tag. Head tags need to follow directly after a div tag, or another head tag. Head tags have type attributes with values that often match the text between the tags. You can see this in the following snippet, from the front part of UT22084-060-008.
Example
<div type="summary">  <head type="summary">Summary</head>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-060-008-1"/>  <p tid="1"> In <title xml:lang="en">Teaching the Relative and Ultimate      Truths</title>, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī is summoned by Buddha Śākyamuni from a    faraway buddha realm to teach in a way that demolishes all dualistic experience.    As Mañjuśrī begins to teach, the main message of the sūtra unfolds as an    explanation of the two truths. The general theme of Mañjuśrī’s discourse is    centered on the particular circumstances in Ratnaketu’s buddha realm, but the    message is equally applicable to the experiences of beings here in this world.  </p> </div> <div type="acknowledgment">  <head type="acknowledgment">Acknowledgments</head>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-060-008-2"/>  <p tid="2">Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the guidance    of Chökyi Nyima Rinpoche. Miguel Sawaya and Andreas Doctor produced the    translation and wrote the introduction. Catherine Dalton compared the draft    translation with the original Tibetan and edited the text. The translators are    grateful to Khenpo Trokpa Tulku, Lama Karma Oser, and Lama Tenzin Sangpo from    Ka-Nying Shedrub Ling Monastery for their assistance in resolving several    difficult passages.</p>  <p tid="3">This translation has been completed under the patronage and supervision    of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.</p> </div>

1.25. <hi>

<hi> (highlighted) marks a word or phrase as graphically distinct from the surrounding text, for reasons concerning which no claim is made. [3.3.2.2. Emphatic Words and Phrases 3.3.2. Emphasis, Foreign Words, and Unusual Language]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
rend
Status Required
Legal values are:
small-caps
subscript
Member of
endnote paragraph
Contained by
core: abbr note
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front
May contain Character data only
Note

In 84000 texts the <hi> element is only used to (1) render small Latin capital letters to be used in the abbreviations for Current Era (CE) and Before Current Era (BCE); and (2) for the second letter used in Kangyur sigla, which sometimes use subscript letters. Note, in the XML markup use the lowercase letter to be rendered as a small capital letter; the parser will render it properly. However the subscript should use lower case or upper case according the proper sigla. See examples below:
Example For marking dates CE or BCE
...active in the eastern Gangetic basin in the fifth century <hi rend="small-caps">bce</hi>.
Example For marking Kangyur sigla
<!--...in notes...--> <note index="10" place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-044-005-209">In K<hi rend="subscript">Q</hi> this title, included within the text, is preceded by this introductory sentence: <!--...etc...--> </note> <!--...in abbreviations section...--> <list type="abbreviations">  <head tid="135" type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>  <item xml:id="UT22084-044-005-111">   <abbr>K<hi rend="small-caps">Q</hi>   </abbr>   <expan>Peking 1737 Kangyur</expan>   <item xml:id="UT22084-044-005-111">    <abbr>G<hi rend="small-caps">bm</hi>    </abbr>    <expan>rnying rgyud bris ma</expan>   </item>   <item xml:id="UT22084-044-005-112">    <abbr>S</abbr>    <expan>Stok Palace (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">stog pho brang bris ma</foreign>) Kangyur</expan>   </item>  </item> </list>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element hi { attribute rend { "small-caps" | "subscript" }, text }

1.26. <idno>

<idno> (identifier) supplies any form of identifier used to identify some object, such as a bibliographic item, a person, a title, an organization, etc. in a standardized way. [2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc. 2.2.5. The Series Statement 3.11.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information]
Module header
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id)
parent-id
Status Optional
Member of
model.nameLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Empty element
Note

In 84000 documents the <idno> element is only used in publication statement. It is used to identify the document by supplying a xml:id attribute, and should be placed just after <availability> inside the <publicationStmt>. When the XML is saved to 84000's database, the xml:id attributes throughout the text will be autmatically generated according to the xml:id value stated here.

A second <idno> element is also found in the <sourceDesc> along with the parent-id attribute.
Example
<publicationStmt>  <publisher> <!--...-->  </publisher>  <availability> <!--...-->  </availability>  <idno xml:id="UT22084-055-001"/>  <date>2018</date> </publicationStmt> <sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh425" type="text"> <!--...-->   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC21412"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>

</content>

   empty
}

1.27. <item>

<item> contains one component of a list. [3.7. Lists 2.6. The Revision Description]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id) att.global.rendition (@rend)
Contained by
core: list
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic l label lb lg list milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

Used as the child elements of a <list>. In 84000 documents they may be used throughout the text typically to separate items in a formal list or an outline in the introduction. See Appendix B.3 for further details on creating outlines. In the back material, <back>, a <list> element with <item>s should also be used in the notes section to separate abbreviations, and it should be used in the glossary to separate individual glossary items.

<item>s may contain the <label> element, to create a bold heading at the beginning of its contents as in the first example of XML markup below:
Example
<div type="section">  <head type="section">Outline</head>  <list type="section">   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-055-001-44"/>   <item>    <label>Chapter 1: The Introduction</label>    <p tid="38">The Buddha Śākyamuni is on Vulture Peak Mountain outside Rājagṛha        with a great gathering of bhikṣus and bodhisattvas. <!--...-->    </p>   </item>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-055-001-45"/>   <item>    <label>Chapter 2: Śālendrarāja</label>    <p tid="40"> <!--...-->    </p>   </item> <!--... etc.-->  </list> </div>
Example
<p tid="1837">Monks, Māra, the evil one, was aroused by these verses and had a dream with thirty-two omens. <ref cRef="F.148.a"/> What are these thirty-two? They are as follows:</p> <list type="bullet">  <item>   <p tid="3007">1. He saw his abode being filled with darkness.</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="3008">2. <div type="glossary">  <list type="glossary">   <item>    <gloss type="place"     xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4791">     <term>Ābhāsvara</term>     <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"/>     <term xml:lang="bo"/>     <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ābhāsvara</term>     <term type="definition">The highest of the three paradises that are the second          dhyāna paradises in the form realm.</term>    </gloss>   </item>   <item>    <gloss type="place"     xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4792">     <term>Abhirati</term>     <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">mngon par dga’ ba </term>     <term xml:lang="bo">མངོན་པར་དགའ་བ།</term>     <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Abhirati</term>     <term type="definition">The realm of Buddha Akṣobhya, beyond countless buddha          realms in the eastern direction.</term>    </gloss>   </item> <!--... etc.-->  </list> </div>

1.29. <label>

<label> contains any label or heading used to identify part of a text. [3.7. Lists]
Module core
Member of
model.labelLike
Contained by
core: item l note p q ref title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic lb milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

Unlike section or chapter tags, label tags do not result in a real structural section of the text. A reader need to click a button to go to the next chapter. The label tag is a less obtrusive heading tag, labeling parts of texts, and not designating major sections. <label>s will appears in bold text in a slight larger type than the rest of the text, but the same color and same font.
Note

One example where you might use the <label> element is in an outline to create a bolder header for one item in the outline, as you can see in the example below.
Example
<div type="section">  <head type="section">Outline</head>  <list>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-055-001-44"/>   <item>    <label>Chapter 1: The Introduction</label>    <p tid="38">The Buddha Śākyamuni is on Vulture Peak Mountain outside Rājagṛha        with a great gathering of bhikṣus and bodhisattvas. Candraprabha asks him for        instruction. The Buddha states that evenness of mind is the one quality that        will bring enlightenment and the attainment of the samādhi called <title xml:lang="en">the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena</title>,        which is described as having an array of qualities that covers all the various        aspects of the path. On hearing this, a multitude of beings attain various        stages of realization; the earth shakes, and a radiance illuminates the        universe.</p>   </item>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-055-001-45"/>   <item>    <label>Chapter 2: Śālendrarāja</label> <!--... etc.-->   </item>  </list> </div>

1.30. <lb>

Although by and large TEI markup is aimed at semantics, not display, the lb tag is used for display purposes, where there should be a linebreak in the display text, but without the tag would not in fact occur. 1.31. <lg>

<lg> (line group) contains one or more verse lines functioning as a formal unit, e.g. a stanza, refrain, verse paragraph, etc. [3.12.1. Core Tags for Verse 3.12. Passages of Verse or Drama 7.2.5. Speech Contents]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type Used to denote specific types of verses such as "sdom" or "bar_sdom" indexes and so forth.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
sdom
bar_sdom
spyi_sdom
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text.
Status Required
rend
Status Optional
Legal values are:
mantra
This <lg> element contains a mantra. The mantra has been formally and clearly declared and so will set apart with indentation and vertical spacing in the 84000 web display. Not all <lg> elements that contain mantras need to be rendered in this way, but generally we do so, when they are formally and clearly declared in the text.
Member of
macro.paraContent model.divPart translation-chapter translation-section translation-subsection-l3 translation-subsection-l4 translation-subsection-l5 translation-subsection-l6
Contained by
core: item note p q ref title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: l milestone
linking: seg
Note

The line group, <element>, should be used to designate each stanza of verse. Individual lines of verse, <l>, are contained as child elements within each <lg>. Like the paragraph, <p> element, each <lg> should be preceded by a milestone and itself be identified with the tid attribute. However, the markup editors do not need to enter these manually as the tid will be automatically applied when the file is saved to the database and the <milestones> will be created by the script.
Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-135"/> <lg tid="92">  <l>“Lord of the World, Buddha,</l>  <l>Illuminator, bringer of benefit,</l>  <l>Elucidate what kind of practice</l>  <l>Will bring the attainment of inconceivable wisdom. {1} </l> </lg>

1.33. <list>

<list> contains any sequence of items organized as a list. [3.7. Lists]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type These "type" values are used to identify the types of lists used in various places throughout the text: "glossary" is applied to the main list in the glossary, "abbreviation" is applied to the list of abbreviations within the notes section of the text. In addition to these two standard lists, the <list> element is also used for any outlines, bulleted lists, or other lists that appear with the actual text itself. In this case, the type attribute with the value "section" or "bullet" should be used, and this will effect how the list is displayed by the parser. The type value "section" will render a list of sections, with some vertical spacing between each item in the list; this is ideal for lists where each item is a paragraph or longer. The type value "bullet" will render the list with indentation but without vertical spacing; this is ideal for short items with identifiers (it isn't necessary that there be an actual "bullet" before each item, this is just the name we are using to distinguish the type). The latter two list types may also be used in combination to create an outline. For instance, see the sample of XML markup below for Toh. 116. For further information on outlines see Appendix B.3
Status Required
Legal values are:
glossary
abbreviations
section
bullet
Member of
model.listLike translation-chapter translation-section translation-subsection-l3 translation-subsection-l4 translation-subsection-l5 translation-subsection-l6
Contained by
core: item l note p q ref title
header: publicationStmt sourceDesc
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: head item milestone p
Note

In general <list> elements may be used to demarcate a formal list anywhere in the text. As a standard, <lists> are used in the "notes" section to list the source material abbreviations key and used in the "glossary" section to list individual glossary entries. Additionally, lists may be used to create outlines or formal lists within the text. Each list must contain <item>s, which contain the individual items on a list. When creating an outline or formal list within the text, the type="section" or type="bullet" must be used. In the web display, type="section" will render items with some vertical spacing between each item, type="bullet" will not have vertical spacing, but will be indented. Multiple <list> elements in combination with these types to format an outline. For example see this outline in Toh. 116 and the XML markup in the example below. For further details on creating outlines see Appendix B.3

A list may contain a <head type="list"> element to create a bold heading at the beginning before the first <item> in the list. Within each <item>, a <label> element can be used to the same effect. See in the XML example below from Toh. 11

Example The following is an outline, notice that the primary list has the type="section" value and the sub-lists following it are marked up type="bullet". This will create and eloquent outline in the web display where the primary sections will be separated with some vertical spacing, but the sub-lists within the major sections will just be indented. See the web display for this list in Toh. 116 here.
<list type="section">  <item>   <p tid="642">I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery      when lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha      states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and      then the city of the pretas. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="643">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the          Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama          and describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and          praises him.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="644">II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="645">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells,          visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This          very sūtra sounds in their realm.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>
Example Here is a simple bullet list used within Toh. 100
<list type="bullet">  <item>   <p tid="309">i. When the JAA states that “non-arising” and “non-cessation” are      epithets of the Tathāgata, it shows that the Buddha is   <emph>unproduced</emph>.</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="310">ii. The nine examples explain what it means for the Tathāgata to be      non-arising and non-cessation (given in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ratna­gotra­vibhāga</title> as the reason for his being unproduced).</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="311">iii. The explanations of all that has been pacified show that, since      all his elaborations and concepts have been pacified, the Tathāgata is   <emph>effortless</emph> with respect to his own activities.</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="312">iv. The next section shows that the Tathāgata realizes for himself      the gates to the realization of the nature of all dharmas, and goes on to      explain the sixteen features of the Tathāgata’s realization (this links to   <emph>not arisen by understanding from others</emph>).</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="313">v. One sentence describes the Tathāgata’s great compassion, showing      that he is endowed with unexcelled awareness and compassion.</p>  </item> </list>
Example Here in this outline from Toh. 11, the <label> element and the <head type="list"> element are both used to great bold headers:
<list type="section">  <head tid="3187" type="list">I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA</head>  <p tid="33">The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical    understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized.    Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters,    with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10. </p>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-031-002-47"/>  <item>   <label>Chapters 1 and 2</label>   <p tid="35">In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection of      wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is the      absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative experiences,      all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional attributes      manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including omniscience.      along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of all things and      the finality of existence, these are all attributes with respect to which a      great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment. Bodhisattvas do perceive      such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative level; in an ultimate sense      they consider them to be illusory, in the manner of a dream and so forth. </p>  </item>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-031-002-48"/>  <item>   <label>Chapter 3</label>   <p tid="37">Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are considered      as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or suffering, with self      or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or signless, having or lacking      aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void, afflicted or purified, arising      or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as entities or non-entities. Deluded      minds would view these phenomena and attributes as absolutely existent whereas      bodhisattvas should train so as to understand that they are all      non-apprehensible—mere designations and conceptualizations. </p>  </item> <!--...etc...--> </list>
Example Here is an example for the standard list used for abbreviations.
<list type="abbreviations">  <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4730">   <abbr>BHS</abbr>   <expan>Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit</expan>  </item>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4731">   <abbr>Chinese</abbr>   <expan>6th century Chinese translation by Narendrayaśas (see Introduction, <ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-11"/> <!--i.7-->)</expan>  </item>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4732">   <abbr>Commentary</abbr>   <expan>Mañjuśrīkīrti (see bibliography) </expan>  </item>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4733">   <abbr>Gilgit</abbr>   <expan>6-7th century Sanskrit manuscript (see Introduction <ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-13"/> <!--i.9--> and bibliography under Dutt).</expan>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>

1.35. <milestone>

<milestone> marks a boundary point separating any kind of section of a text, typically but not necessarily indicating a point at which some part of a standard reference system changes, where the change is not represented by a structural element. [3.10.3. Milestone Elements]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:id, @xml:lang) att.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Datatype ID
unit provides a conventional name for the kind of section changing at this milestone.
Derived from att.milestoneUnit
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
chunk
Member of
model.milestoneLike translation-chapter translation-section translation-subsection-l3 translation-subsection-l4 translation-subsection-l5 translation-subsection-l6
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label lg list note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain Empty element
Note

In the texts, we use the milestone tag to develop as artificial demarcations of the text that will eventually allow people to refer to parts of a text in a somewhat standardized manner. Because there are no consistent natural break points in the original Tibetan texts, the 84000 team decided to use milestone tags. They represent small amounts of texts that are in someway semantically cohesive. They are not tied to a specific text length, but they are not more than a few paragraphs. See the instructions for entering milestones into the text in the appendix

Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-046-001-351"/> <p tid="416">When the Bodhisattva saw that they were settled, he offered them a Dharma teaching and made sure that they understood, became inspired, and were filled with joy.</p>
Content model 
<content>
 <empty/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element milestone
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute xml:id { text },
   attribute unit { "chunk" },
   empty
}

header: notesStmt publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

<note> contains an endnote. Though it appears in the TEI encoded text inline, it is displayed separately in the reading room version, where it is displayed as a pop-up in addition to be listed at the end in the "notes" section. It will presumably be displayed as end notes in the PDF version.
Example All of the <note>s in the front matter and body of text require the following attributes: xml:id, place (with the value "end"), and index.
<l>When he said the letter <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">aṃ</foreign>, out came the statement: “The emergence of what is efficacious (<foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">amoghotpatti</foreign>).”<note index="3" place="end"   xml:id="UT22084-046-001-3071">Translation is based on the Sanskrit.</note> </l>
Example There is one <note> element found at in the <notesStmt> within the <teiHeader>. This <note> simply indicates the last update for the file and is unrelated to the endnotes of the text. For this one occurrence, the <note> will have the type, date-time, user, update, and value attributes; and it does not use the xml:id attribute or the index attribute. This will be maintained by the forms in operations and does not need to be manually entered by markup editors.
<notesStmt>  <note date-time="2019-03-03T20:47:51.274Z"   type="lastUpdated" user="celso">03/03/2019 20:47:51</note> </notesStmt>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <macroRef key="macro.specialPara"/>
  <elementRef key="hi"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element note
{
   att.global.attributes,
   attribute place { list { "end"+ } }?,
   attribute type { text }?,
   attribute index { text }?,
   attribute date-time { text }?,
   attribute user { text }?,
   attribute update { text }?,
   attribute value { text }?,
   ( macro.specialPara | hi )*
}

1.39. <p>

<p> (paragraph) marks paragraphs in prose. [3.1. Paragraphs 7.2.5. Speech Contents]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text.
Status Optional
type
Status Optional
Legal values are:
tantricRestriction
This paragraph warns the reader that this text has a tantric restrition. Thie <p> should be stated in the text's <availability> in the <publicationStmt>
sponsor
This paragraph details the sponsor for the publication of the text, and this should be placed in the "acknowledgements" found int he front of the text.
rend
Status Optional
Legal values are:
mantra
This <p> element contains a mantra. The mantra has been formally and clearly declared and so will set apart with indentation and vertical spacing in the 84000 web display. Not all <p> elements that contain mantras need to be rendered in this way, but generally we do so, when they are formally and clearly declared in the text.
Member of
model.pLike
Contained by
core: item list note q
header: editionStmt licence publicationStmt sourceDesc
textstructure: back body div front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic l label lb lg list milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

This is by far the most common tag used in the markup. Pretty much any prose other than special elements, such as titles, finds itself between an opening and closing <p> tag. Note that each <p> element should be numbered by the tid attribute; however, the markup editors do not need to enter these manually as they will be automatically applied when the file is saved to the database.
Note

Most of the <p> elements should be preceded by a <milestone> element. These will be automatically created by the XSLT script, but markup editors should go through and delete some of them according to the guidelines for entering in milestones.
Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-061-014-1"/> <p tid="1">The sūtra is introduced with the Buddha residing in Anāthapiṇḍada’s grove in Jeta Wood in Śrāvastī together with a great assembly of monks and a great multitude of bodhisatvas. The Buddha then addresses the bodhisatva Jayamati, instructs him on nineteen moral prescriptions, and indicates the corresponding effects of practicing these prescriptions when they are cultivated. </p>
Schematron
<s:report test="not(ancestor::tei:floatingText) and (ancestor::tei:p or ancestor::tei:ab) and not(parent::tei:exemplum |parent::tei:item |parent::tei:note |parent::tei:q |parent::tei:quote |parent::tei:remarks |parent::tei:said |parent::tei:sp |parent::tei:stage |parent::tei:cell |parent::tei:figure )"> Abstract model violation: Paragraphs may not occur inside other paragraphs or ab elements. </s:report>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:l[not(.//tei:note//tei:p[. = current()])]"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div, p, or ab. </s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element p
{
   attribute tid { text }?,

   attribute rend { "mantra" }?,
   macro.paraContent
}

1.40. <ptr>

<ptr> (pointer) defines a pointer to another location. [3.6. Simple Links and Cross-References 16.1. Links]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
target specifies the destination of the reference by supplying one or more URI References
Derived from att.pointing
Status Required
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
model.ptrLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Character data only
Note

This element is used for in-text citations. The target attribute will point to the xml:id value of the appropriate <milestone>, <note>, or <bibl> (The value should be preceded by a "#" as in the example below). In the reading room this will create a link with the appropriate number. The milestone number itself will be automatically rendered in the reading room display, so this shouldn't be entered into the <ptr> element itself, but it may be displayed after as a comment for the editor's reference. Note, that links to other texts, i.e., external links, should be done with the <ref> element and not the <ptr> element. For more information on how to create links and references see Appendix B.4

Example
<p tid="17">A passage from chapter 3 in which the Buddha summarizes for Candraprabha the qualities of a tathāgata (<ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-427"/> <!--3.3-->) seems to have been the source for the short Kangyur sūtra <!--...--> </p>
Schematron
<s:report test="@target and @cRef">Only one of the attributes @target and @cRef may be supplied on <s:name/>.</s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element ptr { attribute target { list { + } }, text }

   attribute status

      "1" | "2.a" | "2.b" | "2.c" | "2.d" | "2.e" | "2.f" | "2.g" | "3" | ""
   },

      element publisher { ( text | name? | lb* | emph* )+ },

         element p
         {
            attribute type { "tantricRestriction" },

         }*,
