1.43. <q>

<q> (quoted) contains material which is distinguished from the surrounding text as a block quote [3.3.3. Quotation]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.ascribed.directed (@toWhom) (att.ascribed (@who))
Member of
model.qLike paragraph translation-chapter translation-section translation-subsection-l3 translation-subsection-l4 translation-subsection-l5 translation-subsection-l6
Contained by
core: author biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic l label lb lg list milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

84000 decuments uses the <q> element to set off a section of text to appear as a block quote in the web display.
Example For example, in The Play in Full, Toh 95, a two paragraphs from the body of the text are quoted in the introduction. Here they are placed within a <q> element to set them apart as a block quote.
<q>  <p tid="9"> “Blessed One, there is an extensive collection of discourses on the    Dharma that bears the name <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalitavistara</title> (<title xml:lang="en">The Play in Full</title>). This teaching illuminates the basic    virtues of the bodhisattvas, showing how the Bodhisattva descended from the    sublime palace in the Heaven of Joy, intentionally entered the womb, and sojourned    in the womb. It shows the power of the place where he was born to a noble family,    and how he surpassed others through all the superior special qualities that he    demonstrated through his actions as a youth. It shows his many unique qualities,    such as his skills in arts, crafts, writing, arithmetic, calculations, astrology,    fencing, archery, feats of physical strength, and wrestling, demonstrating his    superiority to all others in these areas. It shows how he enjoyed his retinue of    consorts and the pleasures of his kingdom. </p>  <p tid="10"> “This teaching proclaims how he attained the result brought about by    the concordant cause of all the bodhisattva activities, showing how he manifested    as a bodhisattva and destroyed the legions of Māra. It explains the ten powers,    the fourfold fearlessness, and the other innumerable qualities of a thus-gone one,    and presents the infinite teachings taught by the thus-gone ones of times past.”  </p> </q>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element q { att.ascribed.directed.attributes, macro.specialPara }

1.44. <ref>

<ref> (reference) defines a reference to another location, possibly modified by additional text or comment. [3.6. Simple Links and Cross-References 16.1. Links]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.pointing (@target) att.cReferencing (@cRef)
type Identifies the type of a reference
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
bampo
sanskrit
key Identifies the Toh. number of the text to which a folio reference is linked to.
Status Optional
Note

This is used for texts for which there are multiple copies found in the Kangyur. Usually, if the texts are identicle but have different folio numbers, we will just use one TEI file for both texts, but the web display will show the appropriate folio references according to key attribute found within the <ref> element. For example see Toh. 193 (UT22084-061-013).
rend Identifies how this reference will be displayed in the reading room.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
hidden
Note

If it has the value "hidden" it will not be displayed in the reading room. This is useful if these references are unecessary and would be excessive for the typical reader, but should be embedded in the text for the purposes of research. For example, some of the folio refs for the Sanskrit in Toh. 11 are hidden in this way, but there is a note about their availability in the text's introduction. See Toh. 11 (UT22084-031-002
work Identifies which work the reference is referring to.
Status Optional
Note

This attribute is needed for Kangyur (or Tengyur) folio references that do not refer to the default--for the Kangyur this is the eKangyur (UT4CZ5369). All Kangyur folio references should have a cRef ("canonical reference") attribute. In the reading room, <ref>s will by default link to the eKangyur, so the work attribute is needed or else the parser will erroneously link to that folio in the eKangyur according to the cRef. When the work attribute is present, the parser will create a link to that work or leave the reference unlinked if the alternate work in not in the database.
Member of
model.ptrLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic l label lb lg list milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

The are three uses for the <ref> element in 84000 texts:
Example First, most commonly, the <ref> element is used to mark all folio references and bampo references in the text that correspond to the physical Dege pages. The actual reference number should be placed in the cRef attribute. This should always follow the format: F.[folio number].["a" for the recto (front) side or "b" for the verso (back) side], for example "F.82.b". Bampo references should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "bampo" and follow the format "B[bampo number]", for example:
<p tid="81">  <ref cRef="F.1.b"/>  <ref cRef="B1" type="bampo"/> I pay homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. <!--...--> </p>
Example The <ref> element is also used for external text citations with the web address entered in to the value of the target attribute. Note that in-text citations should be made with the <ptr> element
<note index="586" place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-1485"> Unidentified Indian musical instrument. It appears in two lists of instruments in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalita­vistara­sūtra</title> (see <title xml:lang="en">The Play    in Full</title>  <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-973">15.39</ref> <!--toh. 95--> and <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-1001">15.67</ref> <!--toh. 95-->) with a stringed instrument preceding and following it, but some recent Tibetan-English dictionaries have “cymbals.”</note>
Example A single <ref> element is also entered into the source description <sourceDesc> in the TEI header, as a child of the <bibl> element to identify the Toh. number of the given text:
<sourceDesc>  <bibl>   <ref>Toh 194</ref>   <biblScope> Degé Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 250.b – 251.a</biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Schematron
<s:report test="@target and @cRef">Only one of the attributes @target' and @cRef' may be supplied on <s:name/> </s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element ref
{
   att.pointing.attributes,
   att.cReferencing.attributes,
   attribute type { "bampo" | "sanskrit" }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   attribute rend { "hidden" }?,
   attribute work { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}

1.49. <teiHeader>

<teiHeader> (TEI header) supplies descriptive and declarative metadata associated with a digital resource or set of resources. [2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module header
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
core: biblScope editor lb title
derived-module-NewODD: consultant sponsor
header: editionStmt publicationStmt
character data
Note

The following description from the University of Michigan is available as part of a PDF at http://www.lib.umich.edu/files/departments/dpp/20101113_06.pdf "The TEI header (<teiHeader>) is the ‘virtual title page’ of a TEI document. It contains meta data (information about the TEI document). <teiHeader> is the first, mandatory child element of the root <TEI> element; therefore, it appears at the top (‘at the head’) of every TEI document. The header meta data provides: 1. bibliographic record of the electronic text as well as the source from which the electronic text is derived 2. documentation of the encoding and editorial principles used in tagging the electronic text 3. terms for indexing, searching, and retrieval 4. a record of changes made to the electronic document. The header contains many specialised elements not found anywhere in the ‘body’ of a TEI document (that is, everything after the close of <teiHeader>). These elements allow for highly structured descriptions of the document. Many parts of the header allow free-form prose descriptions as an alternative to the highly structured descriptions. Few header elements are required, so a header can be quite minimal."
Example
<teiHeader>  <fileDesc>   <titleStmt>    <title type="mainTitle"     xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus        pa</title>    <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">ཚོང་དཔོན་བཟང་སྐྱོང་གིས་ཞུས་པ།</title>    <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the        Merchant</title>    <title type="mainTitle"     xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bhadra­pāla­śreṣṭhi­paripṛcchā</title>    <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་ཚོང་དཔོན་བཟང་སྐྱོང་གིས་ཞུས་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title>    <title type="longTitle"     xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa tshong dpon bzang skyong gis        zhus pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo</title>    <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Questions of        Bhadrapāla the Merchant”</title>    <title type="longTitle"     xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­bhadra­pāla­śreṣṭhi­paripṛcchā­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>    <author role="translatorMain">Translated by Karen Liljenberg and Ulrich        Pagel<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words        of the Buddha.</author>    <author role="translatorEng">Karen Liljenberg</author>    <author role="translatorEng">Ulrich Pagel</author>   </titleStmt>   <editionStmt>    <edition>v 1.3 <date>2017</date>    </edition>   </editionStmt>   <publicationStmt status="1">    <publisher>     <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit        initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern        languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>    <availability>     <licence>      <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>      <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC            BY-NC-ND (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright.             }?

            {

               text*
            }*
          | editor*
          | consultant*
          | sponsor*
         )*
      },
      editionStmt*,
      (
         publicationStmt
       | element publicationStmt
         {
            attribute status { text },
            element idno
            {
               attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID }
            },
            ( element note { text } | element date { text } )*
         }
      ),

      {

         {

            element ref { string },
            text,
            biblScope,

            element citedRange { string }?,
            element author { attribute role { "translatorTib" }, text }*,
            element location
            {
               attribute count-pages { xsd:integer },
               element start
               {
                  attribute volume { xsd:integer },
                  attribute page { xsd:integer }
               },
               element end
               {
                  attribute volume { xsd:integer },
                  attribute page { xsd:integer }
               }
            },

            {
               attribute parent-id { text },
               attribute work { text }?
            },
            element idno
            {
               attribute source-id { text },
               attribute work { text }
            }?
         }+
      },
      element notesStmt
      {

         {
            attribute type { text }?,
            attribute date-time { text }?,
            attribute value { text }?,

         }*
      }?
   }

1.50. <term>

<term> contains a single-word, multi-word, or symbolic designation which is regarded as a technical term. [3.3.4. Terms, Glosses, Equivalents, and Descriptions]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:id, @xml:lang) att.global.rendition (@rend)
type Identifies the term in terms of its relation to the glossary, or its function within the glossary.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
ignore
definition
alternative
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor emph expan foreign gloss item l label note p publisher q ref term title
header: publicationStmt
linking: seg
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic lb milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

In 84000 texts the <term> element is used for glossary entries or to denote the way a string within the text is to linked to the glossary by the parser. See the following examples:
Example Primarily the <term> element is used to list glossary terms in the back matter of a text. For each individual <gloss> element, which constitutes a single glossary entry, a list of several <term> elements are used (see the example below). The first <term> element, which should have no attritutes, shows the English translation of the term or the string used in for that term as it is found in the text. This first <term> element indicates to the parser which word or string of text to link to the glossary entry, and it will create a link for every instance of that term that is found in the text. The next <term> elements that follow within the <gloss> list the Wylie, Tibetan, and Sanskrit for that term, all indicated by the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate value. After that a definition is given in its own <term> element with the type="definition" attribute. Finally, if there are any alternate translations used for the term within the text that should be linked to this gloss, they are listed last each marked by type="alternative". These instances of alternative strings of text will also be linked to the glossary entry wherever they are found in the text. All of this can be seen in the first example below. For further notes about the glossary see Appendix C.
<gloss type="term"  xml:id="UT22084-046-001-2968">  <term>hearer</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> nyan thos </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">ཉན་ཐོས།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">śrāvaka</term>  <term type="definition">A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on    the monastic lifestyle. Also translated as "<term type="ignore">listener</term>."</term>  <term type="alternative">Listener</term> </gloss>
Example The <term> element may also be used in the text itself to alter the way a string of text is to be linked to the glossary. For example, a string of text can bypass being linked if it is placed within a <term type="ignore"> as like the following example. Alternatively, if the parent <gloss> element for an entry is given the attribute mode="marked" then it will only link to instances in the text that are contained within a <term> element. For more details on how the glossary functions on the web page see Appendix C.
<!--A Term is bypassed from being linked within the text with the <term type="ignore"> element.--> Indeed he is a Dharma king who <term type="ignore">guides</term> according to the Dharma. <!-- Alternatively, the gloss is given the atribute mode="marked" --> <item>  <gloss mode="marked" priority="0"   type="term" xml:id="UT22084-044-003-185">   <term>appropriate</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">len pa </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ལེན་པ་</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ādāna</term>   <term type="definition">See “appropriation.”</term>   <term type="alternative">appropriated</term>  </gloss> </item> <!-- Only marked up instances in the text will be highlighted --> <p tid="38"> Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, <term>appropriate</term> another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it <term>appropriate</term> different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?” </p>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element term
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute type { "ignore" | "definition" | "alternative" }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}

1.51. <text>

<text> contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, for example a poem or drama, a collection of essays, a novel, a dictionary, or a corpus sample. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module textstructure
Member of
model.resourceLike
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
textstructure: back body front
Note

In the case of the 84000 translations, the <text> element is opened right below the <teiHeader> element. It includes within it the translated work, as well as the front and back matter.
Example
<text>  <front>   <div type="summary"/> <!--... etc.-->  </front>  <body/>  <back/> </text>

<content>
 <elementRef key="front"/>
 <elementRef key="body" minOccurs="0"/>
 <elementRef key="back" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element text { front, body?, back? }

1.53. <titleStmt>

<titleStmt> (title statement) groups information about the title of a work and those responsible for its content. [2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Attributes Attributes
sponsored Identifies in the <titleStmt>, whether the text has been sponsored in part or full.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
full
part
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
core: author editor title
Note

Appears once in the <teiHeader>. It should contain the nine title variations for each text. This should include four "mainTitle"s and four "longTitle"s (for Wylie, Tibetan, English, and Sanskrit); and one "otherTitle" (for Chinese). If any of these nine default titles are not present, they should contain an empty element as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. It may contain additional title(s) from other sources, but these should be marked as type="otherTitle". Following the titles, there needs to be <author> elements given for each person or group involved in the translation of the text (these authors are the translators of the English, not the original translators of the Tibetan who will be listed later on in the <sourceDesc>). After the <author>s, any <editor>s, <consultant>s, or <sponsor>s may be listed in that order. For these latter three, DO NOT leave empty elements as placeholders if they are not present.
Example
<titleStmt sponsored="full">  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i ting nge    ’dzin</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">བསོད་ནམས་ཐམས་ཅད་བསྡུས་པའི་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན།</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Absorption That Encapsulates All    Merit</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Sarvapuṇya­samuccaya­samādhi</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་བསོད་ནམས་ཐམས་ཅད་བསྡུས་པའི་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་ཅེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i    ting nge ’dzin ces bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Absorption That    Encapsulates All Merit”</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­sarva­puṇya­samuccaya­samādhi­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>  <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh">集一切福德三昧經</title>  <author ref="translators.xml#team-9"   role="translatorMain">Translated by the    Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of    84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-40"   role="translatorEng"/>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-78"   role="translatorEng"/>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-50"   role="translatorEng"/>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-46"   role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa    Tulku</author>  <editor role="mainEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor>  <consultant role="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant>  <sponsor ref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>

 <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
  <elementRef key="title"
   maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
  <classRef key="model.respLike"
   maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>

1.54. <trailer>

<trailer> contains a closing title or footer appearing at the end of a division of a text. [4.2.4. Content of Textual Divisions 4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module textstructure
Attributes Attributes
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text. It is also applicable to trailers which replace the <gi>p<gi/> element.
Status Required
Member of
model.divBottomPart translation-chapter translation-section translation-subsection-l3 translation-subsection-l4 translation-subsection-l5 translation-subsection-l6
Contained by
textstructure: back body div front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic l label lb lg list milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
linking: seg
character data
Note

The trailer should be used for the last sentence of a chapter or text that declares it is the end of that chapter or text. This doesn't include colophons. This element functions like the paragraph, <p>, element and may require a milestone preceding it, and the tid attribute. In the final web display the trailer will be italicized.
Example
<trailer tid="3073">This concludes the third chapter, on the purity of the family.</trailer>
Example Like the <p> element, the <trailer> may contain <note>s or <ref>s, as like the following example.
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-512"/> <trailer tid="3265">Conclusion of the third chapter, “Praise of the Buddha’s Qualities.” <note index="248" place="end"   xml:id="UT22084-055-001-513"> According to    the commentary, the title of this chapter is “Mindfulness of the Buddha’s    Qualities.”</note>  <ref cRef="B2" type="bampo"/> </trailer>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <textNode/>
  <elementRef key="lg"/>
  <classRef key="model.gLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.phrase"/>
  <classRef key="model.inter"/>
  <classRef key="model.lLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.global"/>
 </alternate>
</content>

      text

   )*

2. Model classes

2.1. model.biblLike

2.2. model.biblPart

model.biblPart groups elements which represent components of a bibliographic description. [3.11. Bibliographic Citations and References]
Module tei
Used by

3. Attribute classes

3.1. att.ascribed

att.ascribed provides attributes for elements representing speech or action that can be ascribed to a specific individual. [3.3.3. Quotation 8.3. Elements Unique to Spoken Texts]
Module tei
Members att.ascribed.directed [q]
Attributes Attributes
who indicates the person, or group of people, to whom the element content is ascribed.
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
In the following example from Hamlet, speeches (<sp>) in the body of the play are linked to <castItem> elements in the <castList> using the who attribute.
<castItem type="role">  <role xml:id="Barnardo">Bernardo</role> </castItem> <castItem type="role">  <role xml:id="Francisco">Francisco</role>  <roleDesc>a soldier</roleDesc> </castItem> <!-- ... --> <sp who="#Barnardo">  <speaker>Bernardo</speaker>  <l n="1">Who's there?</l> </sp> <sp who="#Francisco">  <speaker>Francisco</speaker>  <l n="2">Nay, answer me: stand, and unfold yourself.</l> </sp>
Note

For transcribed speech, this will typically identify a participant or participant group; in other contexts, it will point to any identified <person> element.

3.2. att.ascribed.directed

att.ascribed.directed provides attributes for elements representing speech or action that can be directed at a group or individual. [3.3.3. Quotation 8.3. Elements Unique to Spoken Texts]
Module tei
Members q
Attributes Attributes  att.ascribed (@who)
toWhom indicates the person, or group of people, to whom a speech act or action is directed.
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
In the following example from Mary Pix's The False Friend, speeches (<sp>) in the body of the play are linked to <castItem> elements in the <castList> using the toWhom attribute, which is used to specify who the speech is directed to. Additionally, the <stage> includes toWhom to indicate the directionality of the action.
<castItem type="role">  <role xml:id="emil">Emilius.</role> </castItem> <castItem type="role">  <role xml:id="lov">Lovisa</role> </castItem> <castItem type="role">  <role xml:id="serv">A servant</role> </castItem> <!-- ... --> <sp toWhom="#lov"  who="#emil">  <speaker>Emil.</speaker>  <l n="1">My love!</l> </sp> <sp toWhom="#emil"  who="#lov">  <speaker>Lov.</speaker>  <l n="2">I have no Witness of my Noble Birth</l>  <stage toWhom="#serv"   who="emil">Pointing to her Woman.</stage>  <l>But that poor helpless wretch——</l> </sp>
Note

To indicate the recipient of written correspondence, use the elements used in section 2.4.6. Correspondence Description, rather than a toWhom attribute.

3.3. att.cReferencing

att.cReferencing provides an attribute which may be used to supply a canonical reference as a means of identifying the target of a pointer.
Module tei
Members ref
Attributes Attributes
cRef (canonical reference) specifies the destination of the pointer by supplying a canonical reference expressed using the scheme defined in a <refsDecl> element in the TEI header
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
Note

The value of cRef should be constructed so that when the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section 16.2.5. Canonical References) is applied to it the result is a valid URI reference to the intended target.

The <refsDecl> to use may be indicated with the decls attribute.

Currently these Guidelines only provide for a single canonical reference to be encoded on any given <ptr> element.

3.4. att.canonical

att.canonical provides attributes which can be used to associate a representation such as a name or title with canonical information about the object being named or referenced. [13.1.1. Linking Names and Their Referents]
Module tei
Members att.naming date publisher
Attributes Attributes
key provides an externally-defined means of identifying the entity (or entities) being named, using a coded value of some kind.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
<author>  <name key="name 427308"   type="organisation">[New Zealand Parliament, Legislative Council]</name> </author>
<author>  <name key="Hugo, Victor (1802-1885)"   ref="http://www.idref.fr/026927608">Victor Hugo</name> </author>
Note

The value may be a unique identifier from a database, or any other externally-defined string identifying the referent.

No particular syntax is proposed for the values of the key attribute, since its form will depend entirely on practice within a given project. For the same reason, this attribute is not recommended in data interchange, since there is no way of ensuring that the values used by one project are distinct from those used by another. In such a situation, a preferable approach for magic tokens which follows standard practice on the Web is to use a ref attribute whose value is a tag URI as defined in RFC 4151.
ref (reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
<name ref="http://viaf.org/viaf/109557338"  type="person">Seamus Heaney</name>
Note

The value must point directly to one or more XML elements or other resources by means of one or more URIs, separated by whitespace. If more than one is supplied the implication is that the name identifies several distinct entities.

3.5. att.global

att.global provides attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1. Global Attributes]
Module tei
Members editor note
Attributes Attributes  att.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:lang
Status Optional
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan transcribed in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti transcribed in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi transcribed in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese transcribed in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada transcribed in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi transcribed in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali transcribed in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit transcribed in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit transcribed in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil transcribed in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai transcribed in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese transcribed in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic transcribed in Roman script.
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Status Optional
Datatype ID
Note

The xml:id attribute may be used to specify a canonical reference for an element; see section 3.10. Reference Systems.

3.6. att.global.rendition

att.global.rendition provides rendering attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1.3. Rendition Indicators]
Module tei
Members att.global [editor note]
Attributes Attributes
rend (rendition) indicates how the element in question was rendered or presented in the source text.
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
<head rend="align(center) case(allcaps)">  <lb/>To The <lb/>Duchesse <lb/>of <lb/>Newcastle, <lb/>On Her <lb/>  <hi rend="case(mixed)">New Blazing-World</hi>. </head>
Note

These Guidelines make no binding recommendations for the values of the rend attribute; the characteristics of visual presentation vary too much from text to text and the decision to record or ignore individual characteristics varies too much from project to project. Some potentially useful conventions are noted from time to time at appropriate points in the Guidelines. The values of the rend attribute are a set of sequence-indeterminate individual tokens separated by whitespace.

3.7. att.pointing

att.pointing provides a set of attributes used by all elements which point to other elements by means of one or more URI references. [1.3.1.1.2. Language Indicators 3.6. Simple Links and Cross-References]
Module tei
Members ref
Attributes Attributes
target specifies the destination of the reference by supplying one or more URI References
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Note

One or more syntactically valid URI references, separated by whitespace. Because whitespace is used to separate URIs, no whitespace is permitted inside a single URI. If a whitespace character is required in a URI, it should be escaped with the normal mechanism, e.g. TEI%20Consortium.

3.8. att.resourced

att.resourced provides attributes by which a resource (such as an externally held media file) may be located.
Module tei
Members graphic
Attributes Attributes
url (uniform resource locator) specifies the URL from which the media concerned may be obtained.
Status Required
Datatype teidata.pointer

5. Datatypes

5.1. teidata.certainty

teidata.certainty defines the range of attribute values expressing a degree of certainty.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model 
<content>
 <valList type="closed">
  <valItem ident="high"/>
  <valItem ident="medium"/>
  <valItem ident="low"/>
  <valItem ident="unknown"/>
 </valList>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.certainty = "high" | "medium" | "low" | "unknown"
Note

Certainty may be expressed by one of the predefined symbolic values high, medium, or low. The value unknown should be used in cases where the encoder does not wish to assert an opinion about the matter.

5.2. teidata.count

teidata.count defines the range of attribute values used for a non-negative integer value used as a count.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="nonNegativeInteger"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.count = xsd:nonNegativeInteger
Note

Any positive integer value or zero is permitted

5.3. teidata.duration.iso

teidata.duration.iso defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using ISO 8601 standard formats
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.duration.iso = token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }
Example
<time dur-iso="PT0,75H">three-quarters of an hour</time>
Example
<date dur-iso="P1,5D">a day and a half</date>
Example
<date dur-iso="P14D">a fortnight</date>
Example
<time dur-iso="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the last, which may have a decimal component (using either . or , as the decimal point; the latter is preferred). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first ‘time’ number-letter pair.

For complete details, see ISO 8601 Data elements and interchange formats — Information interchange — Representation of dates and times.

5.4. teidata.duration.w3c

teidata.duration.w3c defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using W3C datatypes.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="duration"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.duration.w3c = xsd:duration
Example
<time dur="PT45M">forty-five minutes</time>
Example
<date dur="P1DT12H">a day and a half</date>
Example
<date dur="P7D">a week</date>
Example
<time dur="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the S number, which may have a decimal component (using . as the decimal point). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first ‘time’ number-letter pair.

For complete details, see the W3C specification.

5.5. teidata.enumerated

teidata.enumerated defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • bibl/@type
  • distinct/@type
  • div/@type
  • editor/@role
  • gloss/@type
  • head/@type
  • lg/@type
  • milestone/@unit
  • note/@place
  • ref/@type
  • seg/@type
  • term/@type
  • title/@type
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef key="teidata.word"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.enumerated = teidata.word
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single ‘word’ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

Typically, the list of documented possibilities will be provided (or exemplified) by a value list in the associated attribute specification, expressed with a <valList> element.

5.6. teidata.name

teidata.name defines the range of attribute values expressed as an XML Name.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="Name"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.name = xsd:Name
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which follows the rules defining a legal XML name (see http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#dt-name ): for example they cannot include whitespace or begin with digits.

5.7. teidata.numeric

teidata.numeric defines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef name="double"/>
  <dataRef name="token"
   restriction="(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)"/>
  <dataRef name="decimal"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.numeric =
   xsd:double | token { pattern = "(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)" } | xsd:decimal
Note

Any numeric value, represented as a decimal number, in floating point format, or as a ratio.

To represent a floating point number, expressed in scientific notation, ‘E notation’, a variant of ‘exponential notation’, may be used. In this format, the value is expressed as two numbers separated by the letter E. The first number, the significand (sometimes called the mantissa) is given in decimal format, while the second is an integer. The value is obtained by multiplying the mantissa by 10 the number of times indicated by the integer. Thus the value represented in decimal notation as 1000.0 might be represented in scientific notation as 10E3.

A value expressed as a ratio is represented by two integer values separated by a solidus (/) character. Thus, the value represented in decimal notation as 0.5 might be represented as a ratio by the string 1/2.

5.8. teidata.pattern

teidata.pattern defines attribute values which are expressed as a regular expression.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.pattern = token
Note
A regular expression, often called a pattern, is an expression that describes a set of strings. They are usually used to give a concise description of a set, without having to list all elements. For example, the set containing the three strings Handel, Händel, and Haendel can be described by the pattern H(ä|ae?)ndel (or alternatively, it is said that the pattern H(ä|ae?)ndel matches each of the three strings)
Wikipedia

This TEI datatype is mapped to the XSD token datatype, and may therefore contain any string of characters. However, it is recommended that the value used conform to the particular flavour of regular expression syntax supported by XSD Schema.

5.9. teidata.pointer

teidata.pointer defines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • editor/@ref
  • ptr/@target
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="anyURI"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.pointer = xsd:anyURI
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax. Note that the values themselves are encoded using RFC 3987 Internationalized Resource Identifiers (IRIs) mapping to URIs. For example, https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/% is encoded as https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/%25 while http://موقع.وزارة-الاتصالات.مصر/ is encoded as http://xn--4gbrim.xn----rmckbbajlc6dj7bxne2c.xn--wgbh1c/

5.13. teidata.temporal.w3c

teidata.temporal.w3c defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition specification.

5.15. teidata.version

teidata.version defines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • TEI/@version
Content model

 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.version = token { pattern = "[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}" }
Note

The value of this attribute follows the pattern specified by the Unicode consortium for its version number ( http://unicode.org/versions/ ). A version number contains digits and fullstop characters only. The first number supplied identifies the major version number. A second and third number, for minor and sub-minor version numbers, may also be supplied.
