Appendix A Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors

Appendix A.1 Enter the Word DOC into the Template

(If this hasn't already been done by the copy editors. However, if you receive a text from the copy editors, it is important to check their work and make sure the text has been placed properly into the template.)

  • In general you can follow the instructions written in the template.
  • Paste the text into all the appropriate sections using the "Heading 1, 2, or 3" styles to outline the text. Make sure that the style “Heading 4” or higher isn’t used anywhere in the document, as that information will be lost in the conversion process. Any headings for fourth level subsections (or higher) written by the translator should be set to the “Normal” style in the style set and be tagged with <level 4 header> or similar tags. These subsections will need to be manually created with <div> elements when you edit the XML.
  • Apply all the various styles to the italics in the text.
  • Apply the "verse" style to verses and format the verses (change the display settings to show paragraph marks and line breaks so you can see more clearly whether they are formatted correctly).
  • In some cases the copy editors may have left comments for the markup editors with the MS Word comments feature. The script will convert these into <note> elements that will have the "place" attribute with the value of "comment_from_copyeditor_to_markup_editor." I have intentionally set this up to be highlighted by the schema as an error, so that the copy editors may highlight any unusual formatting or other issues that need to be addressed by the markup editors. You may leave these in and address them as you work on the XML or alternatively keep a backup of the .docx and reference the comments from there. If you don't want to see them in the XML, make a backup of the .docx and select "Delete All Comments in the Document" from the review pane in Word before sending the document through the conversion script.

Appendix A.2 Transform the New DOCX To TEI-XML

Running the Document through the Conversion Script:
  • Use this conversion app on the project management page. First click on the "Search" tab and locate the file using the Tohoku number. Once you have found the text click on "edit headers", From there you can expand the "submissions" section and upload the .docx there. The app will perform the conversion and the output .xml file can be found in the 84000 Collaboration/apps/84000-import-data folder. There will be a unique folder created with the name of the texts xml:id number.
  • Occasionally the app may be down or the project management page may give you a permissions error. If it says that permission is denied you should email the lead technician who handles the server's permissions (Dominic). Alternatively, it is also possible to convert the word .docx created in the template through the oXgarage website or it's mirror site. Convert the file to a "TEI P5 XML Document" and run our own .xslt script on the document. The .xslt script is in apps/84000-import-data/xsl. (Instructions for running an .xslt script can be found in Appendix H)
Checking the XML Conversion before You Begin Editing:
  • This should create a file that is closer to what we want. However, the script is definitely not perfect, and many sections will need some reworking.
  • If the "verse" styles were applied appropriately in the template, then the script should put them correctly into <lg> and <l> elements. It should also preserve and convert any italic markup within the verses. The script is able to do both because in MS Word the "verse" is a paragraph style and all the italic markups are character styles. However, for the script to work properly the individual lines of verse need to be separated by line breaks, and the stanzas themselves need to be separated by paragraph breaks. There are instructions for how to do this in the template, but this process can be a bit finicky, so you should double check some of the verses to make sure the conversion has worked properly. Refer to the section on the <lg> element to see how verses need to be formatted.
  • Another note about the script to keep in mind is that the script is designed to automatically create divisions with <div> elements in the markup whenever the copy editors use the "heading 1," "heading 2," or "heading 3" styles in the template. This will create up to three levels of <div>s. As mentioned above any fourth level <div>s or further should be placed into tags by the copy editor and you will need to create the <div>s manually when you edit the XML. Occasionally, the copy editor will put a heading into the "heading 1" or "heading 2" style but they will mistakenly leave the paragraph break at the end of the heading's text in the "normal" style. The script generates the <div> elements according to these paragraph breaks, so in this case, it will not create the proper division. Usually it is easy enough to correct these in either the template .docx or in the .xml, but in some cases it may save you some time if you can identify and fix them before the conversion. For example, this happened in the bibliography of a text, and because the bibliography entries were nested with one <div> instead of two, the script rendered them into <p> elements instead of <bibl> elements as is required.
  • The script has a section for making appendices, which should appear in the <back> after the bibliography. However, since not all the texts have appendices, and since appendices could appear in many different forms such as lists, outlines, Sanskrit sources, etc., the script only converts these into the minimal default paragraphs or verses. You may need to reformat the markup in the section extensively or paste it in from the word file and mark it up from there. If there are more appendices in the future, or a particularly large appendix that needs to be extensively edited, we will develop the script to convert the appendices in a more detailed way.
  • If there is some unusual formatting or other issue that is preventing the script from converting the text properly, one strategy for isolating the problem is to divide the text into three pieces (front material, body, and back material), convert each section one be one, and then paste them into the final .xml. For this purpose we have created a Dummy Template which is just the minimal format for an 84000 text. Try pasting the smaller sections of the text into the Dummy Template and convert them one by one.

Appendix A.3 Edit the XML

Merge the Converted XML into the Placeholder File:
  • When you have finished converting the document into an TEI-XML file, it is time to transfer it into the translations folder. There should already be a placeholder file for each of the Kangyur and Tengyur texts. Go to 84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > tei > translations, and you will see the "kangyur" and "tengyur" folders. Each of these folders in turn contain a "placeholders" folder and a "translations" folder. Find the placeholder file right click and select "cut" then move it into the sibling "translations" folder by right and select "paste" (don't use "copy" and "paste" as this will reset the files permissions).
  • You can then begin pasting the text from the XML you just converted into the placeholder text. The placeholder files mostly just contain the <teiHeader>, however, most of this is important information and should not be overwritten. The converted XML will have directions in the form of comments, which will tell you specifically what elements within the teiHeader need to be added to the placeholder, and which to be left as is. In general, try to preserve all pertinent information from both sources, and if there is any data that seems to be contradictory, comment out the additional data and make a note of this in your final list of notes and issues.
  • The placeholder <titleStmt> should already contain some of the titles for the text, but the English titles should be updated according to the new translation (in this one case it is fine to overwrite the placeholder titles), add any of the titles that are not already in the placeholder. There should be a minimum of nine titles: 4 Main Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), 4 Long Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), and 1 Chinese. Any additional variant <title>s (whether coming from the converted file or already present in the placeholder) should be added after this as type="otherTitle". The actual order of the titles doesn't matter because the parser will display them in the same order no matter what order the XML is in, but if one or more of the nine default titles are not present, leave an empty element there as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>.
  • Also check the original word document for additional titles or authors, as the conversion script is quite rigid, and some of them might disappear if they were not entered properly.
  • Alternatively, if you prefer, the titles can also be edited from the project management page using the original .docx as a reference. The project management page is linked directly to the teiHeaders in the XML.
Edit the Contributors from Project Management
  • Open the project management page. Find the text by searching the Toh number, then click on "edit headers" From here click on the "contributors" section.
  • The app's window should show you all the contributor's information as it currently appears in both the <author role="translatorMain"> node and in the "acknowledgements". Here you will need to enter in each contributor's (a) role, (b) their official name in the data base, which should be selected from a drop down list, and (c) the "expression:" for how it appears as written in the acknowledgements. When you click on "save" it will automatically add these contributors to the teiHeader with the proper element and proper ref identification.
Edit Text Status from Project Management
  • Click on the "status". From this window you will be able to see various features regarding the text's status, some of which corresponds to data in the <teiHeader>, and some of this data is contained in separate data files. In the right column you will see a checklist for "Current Tasks". Here you can see the text's current stage within the work flow. You may "add to current tasks" as needed.
  • To display the text on the Utilities page, you will need to change the "status" attribute within the <publicationStmt>. It should be at "2.b" during the copyediting phase, and now for the markup you should change it to "2.a." (Although it has probably already been updated by the script). The text will now appear on the Utilities Page. Here you will be able to see how the text will be displayed on the webpage before it is published on the official 84000 page. Click on the link that says "html" next to the text to see the web display.
Apply the Schema:
  • The schema should already be applied to the placeholder file, but if you need to apply the schema directly it is located in “84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > schema > current > translation.rng.” You will see any schema errors as red bars on the right column in the oXygen window. Checking the schema is the best way to see if the XML is going to work correctly in the parser. If later on you have trouble saving to the database, or if you can save to the database but the web page does not display the text, then start by checking for schema errors in oXygen. If it says that there is an error where you don’t think there is really an error, but you need to check the XML on the web display, you can comment-out that section with comment tags:
    <!-- --> (or highlight and press Ctrl-Shift “,” on PC or Command-Shift "m" on mac). Then you will be able to temporarily block all the seeming schema errors to help identify the problem.
  • You will initially see many schema errors for some missing attributes such as "xml:id"s and "tid"s. Note that all "xml:id" attributes, "tid" attributes in the <p> elements, and "index" attributes in the <note> elements will be added automatically when you save and reload the XML, so you don't need to worry about adding these. However, in the <teiHeader> within the <publicationStmt> there is an element for the id number for the text, <idno>. The script should just say "DUMMY" here so you will need to enter the number manually (you should be able to look up the text number as it is posted on the Trello board "UT22084-###-###"). Then the database will automatically generate the xml:id attributes throughout the text based on this.
  • In case there is an error in any of the "xml:id" or "tid" attributes due to duplicates, then you can regenerate them by deleting any problematic ones, saving the file, and then re-opening. The "xml:id" and "tid" will be generated wherever they are missing. If not, email the lead technician and they will make sure they are regenerated. It is fine if the "xml:id" attributes are not in order as long as they each have a unique value.
Some General Guidelines for Editing the XML:
  • While editing the XML, I usually use a previously edited and published TEI document as a model to make sure everything is formatted in the same way. This can be helpful, especially if this is your first time marking up a text or if you haven't done the markup for some time.
  • In general, while going through the text, it is important to periodically refer back to the .docx you received from the copy editor. If the document has an unusually formatted outline, some portions of text may be lost in the XSLT conversion. A good way to check this is to open the original .docx and look at the outline of the text (on PC go to “View” and check the box that says “Show Navigation Pane”; on Mac go to “View” > “Sidebar” > “Document Map Pane”; this might be different for other versions of Word). For example, if there are any fourth-level headers or extra divisions in the summary or acknowledgements, these sections may disappear. It is particularly good to check the front material and the bibliography for anything unusual.
  • When you first get to the <body> of the text, you may notice that the title has been repeated with two lines containing separate <p> and <milestone> tags. For example:
    <body>  <div type="translation">   <head type="translation"> The Translation </head>   <head type="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra</head>   <head type="titleMain">Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality</head>   <milestone unit="chunk"/>   <p> The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra   </p>   <milestone unit="chunk"/>   <p> Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality   </p> <!--...body of the text...-->  </div> </body>
    The reason for this, is the script has a safeguard to display any text within the first main <div> but not included in the first second level <div>. A not ideal consequence of this safeguard results in this repetition of the first two lines, which simply needed to be deleted manually. So the above example should be edited to look as follows:
    <body>  <div type="translation">   <head type="translation"> The Translation </head>   <head type="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra</head>   <head type="titleMain">Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality</head> <!--...body of the text...-->  </div> </body>
  • If either one of the introduction, main translation, and/or bibliography have only one section you will probably see this heading at the beginning of their second level <div> element:
    <head>Main Section</head>
    This is actually a placeholder from the template and should be removed, as the heading from the previous <div> element will provide the heading "Introduction" or "The Translation."
  • If there were any italics that were missed in the copy editing phase, they will appear with a schema error in an element called "fix." You will need to manually fix these and replace them with the appropriate element, whether it be <foreign>, <title>, <distinct>, etc. Sometimes these may be just italicized punctuation that the copy editor or author made by mistake, in which case you can go ahead and remove these tags.
  • Double check that the tag <hi rend="small-caps"> is used for any small capital letters in the text. This includes any abbreviations for CE ("Common Era") or BCE ("Before Common Era") in dates. Note that the lowercase letter needs to be used for small-caps, for example:
    In the year 2000 <hi rend="small-caps">bce</hi>
    Then the parser will render this as small capital "BCE".
    Also, some of the Kangyur sigla in the abbreviations and notes use subscript letters. For Kangyur sigla we use the Vienna system, which you can check the spelling here. Note that most of the sigla use a Capital letter followed by a lowercase one, but the sigla from the Peking Group, Mongolian, and Nyingma Kangyurs use a capital letter followed by subscript letters, and these second letters should have the <hi rend="subscript"> tag. Here either the lowercase or uppercase letter should be used according to the definitive sigla, for example:
    Peking 1737 PK = K<hi rend="subscript">Q</hi>, rnying rgyud bris ma = G<hi rend="subscript">bm</hi>.
    Do not use any unicode for the small caps or subscript such as "ʙᴄᴇ" or "ᵥ" as this won't display consistently in the reading room for all browsers. The script should convert all small-caps and subscript from the template with the proper tag, if "small-caps" and "subscript" were applied in the template using MS Words Font dialog (Format > Font), but these should be double checked in the XML.
  • Typically there will be many left over "<hi>" elements after the script has converted the text. With the one exception of rendering small capital and subscript letters (as shown in the example above) we don't really don't use any of these <hi> elements in our mark up. Most of these are just remnants of formatting from the word document, and the script should convert all of these to type="wordfile-remnant". The refactoring tool is very helpful for removing them. In the oXygen menu go to "Tools" > XML Refactoring, and then select "unwrap element." This operation removes the "<hi>" tags but leave the text within them untouched, however we only want to remove the <hi type="wordfile-remnant"> elements but not the <hi rend="small-caps"> and <hi rend="subscript">elements. To do this, after selecting the "unwrap element" operation, it will ask us for the Target Elements (XPath). For this we should enter the XPath: hi[@type="wordfile-remnant"] This will only remove the <hi> elements with this attribute. Now you can click on "Next" and then "Preview". Note that it will ask you to save all opened editors, so be sure to close any editor windows that you don't want saved. The Refactoring tool is very useful for removing or changing other unwanted markup as well. However, use some caution when making global changes like this. You will want to make sure you aren't removing any important data. Using the preview mode, you can see how a command is going to effect the text. In most cases, we will want to remove all the "<hi type="wordfile-remnant">" tags, but before using the refactoring tool to remove them, be sure to take a quick glance through the text and make sure the <hi> tags are not being used for a significant markup that may have been missed or unrepresented in the copy editing phase. If you are unsure, or if the <hi> tags are too messy to tell, save a backup copy of the markup before removing them with the refactoring tool, then you can check them once more after you finish marking up the text.
  • Look for any weird tags that shouldn't be there like "type="endnote text"" or any other relics from the oxgarage/script conversion.
  • Look for any mistakes: typos, mislabeled tags, etc.
  • As you do any major work on the text, it is a good idea to occasionally update the version number as a reference for file backups. For guidelines on how and when to do this, see Appendix K: Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document.
Editing the References in the XML:
  • All the references such as [F.100.a], etc. need to be entered into <ref> elements with the "cRef" attribute, thus [F.100.a] should look like this:
    <ref cRef="F.100.a"/>
    Note that this is the standard we are using for all folio references: it should be an "F" followed by a period, a number, another period, and the letter "a" or "b." To put the bracketed folios into the <ref> element I usually use a search and replace with regular expressions. To do this open a find and replace box, check the "Regular Expressions" box and search for:
     \[(F\.\d+\.[ab])\] 
    Replace with:
    <ref cRef="$1"/>
    Or if they forgot to add the second period before that "a" or "b," like "[F.100a]", then search for:
                    \[(F\.\d+)([ab])\] 
    And replace with:
    <ref cRef="$1.$2"/>
    Regular expressions are very useful for such tasks, just be careful not to search and replace any text or markup you did not intend to. For example, the introduction of a text might quote a folio reference number in the same format in which it was applied in the body of the text, say "[F.100.a]". We definitely don't want this instance placed into a <ref> element, so be careful not to inadvertently replace it with a "replace all" command. Usually when I do a search and replace, I replace a few individual items to make sure it is working properly and there aren't any anomalies before I do a "replace all" command. If you aren't familiar with regular expressions this is a good reference website, and there are a lot of tutorials on youtube too.
  • Sometimes there will be Bampo references and hidden references. To work with these see the section on the <ref> element.
  • When a <ref> comes between two paragraphs, it is better to place it at the end of the preceding paragraph rather than the beginning of proceeding one, as this will be less distracting for the reader. The very first <ref>, however, must be placed at the beginning of the paragraph as there is no other choice.
  • Note, there are some texts that are duplicated in multiple sections of the Kangyur. For example The Prophecy of Sri_Mahadevi is found twice in the Kangyur as Toh. 193 and 739. Theses are both word for word exactly the same, but the folio references are going to be different for each duplicate version of the text. So in this situation we just use one TEI file, "061-014_toh193,739" but the folio references are differentiated with the key attribute which will relate each individual <ref> to the corresponding key that is declared within that version's <bibl> element found in the TEI's initial <sourceDesc>. For example, in 061-014_toh193,739's <sourceDesc>:
    <sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh193" type="text">   <ref>Toh 193</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 246.a–250.b</biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>   <location count-pages="10">    <start page="493" volume="61"/>    <end page="502" volume="61"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14668"/>  </bibl>  <bibl key="toh739" type="text">   <ref>Toh 739</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 94 (rgyud ’bum, tsha), folios 230.a–234.b</biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>   <location count-pages="10">    <start page="461" volume="94"/>    <end page="470" volume="94"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC21415"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
    Then if you look at each individual folio references they will be differentiated by the key like this:
    ... <p tid="9">  <ref cRef="F.246.a" key="toh193"/>  <ref cRef="F.230.a" key="toh739"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. </p>
    Now the parser will only display the appropriate folio references, e.g., when you click on Toh. 193 it will show the references for Toh. 193 but not those for 739 and vice-versa. Sometimes the page breaks between the folios will be in the same place in the eKangyur but often they are different so you may need to go in and find them all manually if they were not written in by the translator.
Other Issues to Check For while Editing the XML:
  • The copy editors have been instructed to put any block quotes into <q> tags, however the conversion script inconveniently converts all of the angular brackets into their character codes &lt; and &gt;. These will need to be corrected and any <p> or <lg> elements should be placed inside any <q> elements. For example:
    <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-047-002-3"/> <q>  <lg tid="4">   <l>“Space has no abode;</l>   <l> It is free from elaboration, and stainless.</l>   <l>Your mind is the same as space,</l>   <l>And you are free of any point of reference: </l>   <l> I bow to you!”</l>  </lg> </q>
    Occasionally the copy editors might forget to put in tags for block quotes. Therefore, refer back to the original .docx if it seems like a section should be put into block quotes. Add a note to the final list of questions and issues if there is a section that was not set apart as a block quote that you believe should have.
  • Check for any other tags that the copy editor may have entered in by doing a quick search for the character codes for angular brackets: &lt; or &gt; this might include <q> elements or level 4 headers that cannot be handled by the script.
  • <note>s cannot be left in headers or titles. Move these notes to an appropriate place within the text itself.
  • Within the notes section of the text the template and script will create an abbreviations section even if there isn't one. If there isn't any abbreviations section in the original docx. you can delete the abbreviations header but leave the section for notes. It should just look like this:
    <div type="notes">  <head type="notes">Notes</head> </div>
  • Any formal lists or outlines within the text should be marked up with the <list> element, which must also have the type attribute with the value "section" or "bullet." "Section" should be used for longer items of text, and it will render them with some vertical spacing between each item. "Bullet" should be used for shorter items and will create some horizontal indentation (it isn't necessary for there to be actual "bullets" in the list, this is just what we have named it). These types can be used in any combination to create an outline. For further details on outlines and some examples see Appendix B.3.
  • Check that all the <div> elements are marked up with the proper type attributes. See the documentation for the <div> element to see the list of acceptable values. Note that a "prologue" or "colophon" should be marked as such and not as a "section." Also, each <div> should be accompanied by a <head> that has its own matching type attribute; however, there is one exception to this, <div type="section"> may be left without a <head> if the author did not provide one, this will usually be the case in the Introduction, Main Translation, or Bibliography whenever there is just one section and by default it is placed into a second level <div type="section"> wrapped within a first level <div type="introduction"> or <div type="translation">. In this case the parser will read the <head>s from the main first level <div> and the second level <div type="section"> will not require an additional <head>.
  • The script doesn't distinguish between chapters and sections, so the type value for all the "chapters" needs to be applied manually. Also, "chapter"s should contain a <head> type="chapter" element with some kind of enumeration, i.e., "chapter one," "chapter two," etc. If there is a formal title it should be contained in a <head> type="chapterHead" element following the first <head>. For example:
    <div type="chapter">  <head type="chapter">Chapter 32</head>  <head type="chapterTitle">The Teaching on the Nature of All Phenomena</head> <!--...chapter text...--> </div>
  • Some texts have <trailer>s at the end of each chapter, for example in Toh. 11:
    <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-031-002-1980"/> <trailer tid="3216">This completes the twenty-second chapter from the <title xml:lang="en">Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom in Ten Thousand Lines</title>, entitled “Cultivation.”</trailer>
    Be default the script will convert every paragraph into a <p> element, so these <trailer>s should be manually applied if they appear at the end of each chapter.
  • As you are working with the TEI texts, you may encounter various problems that require you to search for specific pieces of code or text within the markup. The XQuery/XPath Builder is a useful tool for searching for specific instances of text. See Appendix J, for further details on how to use the XQuery/XPath Builder.

Appendix A.4 Edit Milestones

Milestones should be generated automatically by the script before every <p> element and <lg> element; however, we don't use milestones as uniformly as this, and some of the milestones will need to be taken out (for instructions on how to do this see appendix D). While editing in oXygen, it can be easier to edit milestones while in "author mode" (go to "Author" in the menu bar and click on "Switch to Author Mode"). This will show the layout of the text more clearly and you can remove the milestones by double clicking on them and hitting delete.

Appendix A.5 Check the Alignment for Folio References

Next we need to check to make sure the Folio References displayed on the web page are in alignment with the eKangyur. This require some minimal knowledge of Tibetan, so please have another editor check this for you if you don't know how to read Tibetan.

When you check the web display on the Utilities page, go to the main translation and click on a folio reference, e.g., "[F.100.a]." This should cause the eKangyur text to pop up. Make sure that the eKangyur page that pops up is the correct page that corresponds to the English translation. You don't need to go through every folio in the text, just check the first two folio refs and the very last one.

Most likely they will be aligned automatically and a correction will not be needed. However, due to a blank page or error in the eKangyur the alignment of the pages might be off by one or more pages. To fix the alignment we have created an .xml called "folio mapping" in apps > 84000-data > config > folio-mapping.xml. It should look something like this:

<folio-mappings xmlns="http://read.84000.co/ns/1.0">  <mapping page-multiplier="2"   page-offset="-1" source="ekangyur" volume-add="126">   <range end="91.a" page-offset="411"    start="1.b" volume="31"/>   <range end="397.a" page-offset="410"    start="92.b" volume="31"/>   <range end="63.a" page-offset="-2"    start="63.a" volume="90"/>   <range end="87.b" page-offset="-3"    start="63.b" volume="90"/>   <range end="156.a" page-offset="-3"    start="150.b" volume="90"/>  </mapping> </folio-mappings>

Here the "volume" corresponds to the volume of the text in the Degé (add 126 to this to find the corresponding eKangyur volume). "Start" and "end" should correspond to the text you need to adjust, and the "page-offset" will adjust the alignment up with a positive integer or down with a negative one. It should only need to be adjusted by one or two pages, but if you need to reference the eKangyur it can be found in apps > eKangyur > data > UT4CZ5369 (don't use W4CZ5369).

Note, that if the text contains duplicate versions within the Kangyur (such as Toh. 212/520/980), the folio alignment will need to be checked for each version individually.

***Special Case for Volumes 81, 83, and 88 of the Degé Kangyur/eKangyur*** There is a variation due to the addition of texts in the post par phud printings, which includes our eKangyur in volumes 81, 83 and 88, which are not in the par phud printing such as W22084. In volumes 81 and 83, this only concerns some texts added to the very end of the volume, but for volume 88 the Bodhimaṇḍasyālaṃkāralakṣadhāraṇī (byang chub snying po’i rgyan ’bum gyi gzungs) This work has the same Tibetan title as Toh 509, but a different Sanskrit title (Toh 509 is Bodhigarbhālaṃkāralakṣadhāraṇī). While this is confusing, it is also presumably the reason why the extra text was inserted at this point. If the orginal translator used a par phud printing this then off sets Volume 88 by 17 folios for all texts after Toh. 508. In this situation, because the folio references will not match up with those in the eKangyur, our solution has been to put use both folio references. The one that links to the eKanyur will be the default <ref> element and the <ref> that refers to the alternate printing (likely W22084) should have this stated by a work attribute within the <ref> element. See for example from toh. 520:

<ref cRef="F.41.a" key="520" work="W22084"/> <ref cRef="F.58.a" key="520"/>

Here in the web display both references will be visible but only the one without the "work" attribute will have a clickable link to the eKangyur.

Appendix A.6 Transform and Edit the Glossary

  • Before transforming the glossary in the Excel spreadsheet with the script, make sure that the spreadsheet is formatted properly. It should have three sheets labeled "Terms", "People", and "Places" (if the names of the sheets don't say this exactly, the script won't apply the correct type to the <gloss> elements). Each sheet needs to have five columns that are exactly arranged as follows: (A) Tibetan Wylie, (B) Sanskrit, (C) Translation, (D) Definition, and (E) Alternatives.
  • Note that occasionally you may get a spreadsheet with an additional column of Chinese terms. If this is the case, there is a separate script for spreadsheets with Chinese. In this case the six columns should be arranged exactly as follows: (A) Tibetan Wylie, (B) Chinese, (C) Sanskrit, (D) Translation, (E) Definition, and (F) Alternatives.
  • Using a Macro to Correct Initial Apostrophes: When you receive a glossary file, in Excel, it’s likely there will be hidden apostrophes in the wylie column. This happens when a straight apostrophe is typed at the beginning of the word, as in the case of an a-chung prefix, "འ". Excel uses straight apostrophes to override the cell's format when typing numbers so that it considers it as text. In the process it hides this initial apostrophe, although there actually is an apostrophe in the cell, i.e., it disappears unless one actually clicks on the cell and looks in the text box at the top of the screen. In some cases the translator may have entered two apostrophes by mistake, or put one where their shouldn't be one. In all cases, these will need to be corrected, as the translator should not use straight apostrophes in the wylie text at all, but only use left curving apostrophes (’) (otherwise the script will not display proper Tibetan Unicode below them). To fix this you should run the following macro in Excel. This macro will convert each initial straight apostrophe. However, most often these are a spelling error in the wylie transliteration and will need to be corrected (each instance must be verified in a Tibetan dictionary). To make these instances easy to find, the macro also adds “111” so that it’s easy to make a search for these cells. The “111” is just a marker and will obviously need to be removed too.
  • In case you don't know how to run a macro in Excel, there are many tutorials available on Youtube for both PC and Mac. There might be some differences depending on the version of your Excel software, but they should be pretty straightforward. You may be prevented from running a macro if the file is "shared"; you may have to go to the "Review" tab, click on "Share Workbook," and uncheck the box to share the file with other users (this might be slightly different on Mac). Then you should be able to run the macro without any problem. Here is the macro. Paste the following code into a module window and hit "run":

    Sub AposChange()
    Dim Rng As Range, Cell As Range
    ThisWorkBook.Activate
    Set Rng = Cells.SpecialCells(xlConstants)
    Cells(Rows.Count, Columns.Count).Copy
    For Each Cell In Rng
    If Cell.PrefixCharacter = "'" Then
    Cell.Value = "111 ’" + Cell.Value
    Cell.PasteSpecial Operation:=xlPasteSpecialOperationAdd
    End If
    Next Cell
    Application.CutCopyMode = False
    End Sub

  • Here is an example. When you look at the spreadsheet you will see:
    ’khor ba ’jig
    But in the file there is actually a hidden apostrophe:
                    '’khor ba ’jig
    So after running the macro script it will become:
    111 ’’khor ba ’jig
    In this example there should be no hesitation about what to remove, but in other cases you may need to check in the dictionary.
  • Transform the Glossary with the XSLT Script: At some point we will develop our own script to do this, but until then use oxgarage at: http://www.tei-c.org/oxgarage/. Select the option to change a Spreadsheet “Microsoft Excel .xlsx” to “TEI P5 XML Document.”
  • Download and open the XML in oXygen and use the .xslt stylesheet to transform the XML document. To do this:
    • A. Click on “Configure Transformation Scenarios” (it should be a wrench with a red arrow on the oXygen ribbon).
    • B. Select “New” > “XML transformation with XSLT.”
    • C. For the XSL URL: click on the drop-down menu next to the folder and select “Browse Data Source Explorer.”
    • D. Select the file in 84000-data/xslt called "oxGto84000-gloss.xsl" (or use "oxGto84000-gloss.xsl-wChinese" if the glossary contains six columns with Chinese Terms). If you get a permissions error email Dominic and ask him to give you permissions to open the file.
    • E. For the “Transformer”: select “Saxon-PE 9.6.0.7” from the drop-down menu.
    • F. Click on the “Output” tab and check the box that says “Open in Editor.”
    • G. Click OK, and then select “apply associated” (the transformation scenario you just made should be ticked under “projects”).
  • Continuing with step A.6 Transforming and Editing the Glossary: If you get the script to work, or have someone else convert it for you, you can then paste it into the XML text you are working on. Use another already-published TEI file as a model.
  • The script should be able to convert all three sheets in the combined .xlsx file in one go and create the appropriate type attribute (term, person, or place) if the sheets were labeled properly. However, if one of the sheets isn't converting properly, try breaking the three sheets into three separated .xlsx files and converting each one individually.
  • Edit the glossary. Note that when you save the file to the database it will add the “xml:id” automatically so you don’t need to worry about adding these. You will probably need to remove several empty <item> elements that were converted from empty cells at the bottom of each sheet. Also remove entries that were converted from the spreadsheet's headings i.e., Tibetan, Sanskrit, Translation, Definition, etc.
  • If the script "oxGto84000-gloss.xsl-wChinese" was used, the script assumes that the Chinese terms will be typed in Chinese characters and will be set to xml:lang="zh" by default.
  • Note that the database will also automatically generate Tibetan script and add it as a <term xml:lang="bo"/> element based on the Wylie glossary entries. The code should look within the glossary for any <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"/> and create the matching "bo" term wherever there isn't one. So be sure to save the file, close it, reopen, and check that the Tibetan entries have been properly added.
  • Check for errors and make sure the tags are nested properly. Use a previously-edited 84000 TEI XML as a model. You might want to save it first so that it automatically adds all the attributes and so forth.
  • Note that any italics used in the definitions for glossary items need to be entered in manually. By default the script will place all italics found in the definitions column into <title xml:lang=""> tags, but you will need to go in and change some of these into <foreign> tags where appropriate and add the proper type and xml:lang attributes as needed.

Appendix A.7 Add Optional Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit Chains

Next, optional soft-hyphens should be entered for any long Sanskrit chains. The guidelines for doing this are shown in Appendix E: Guidelines for entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit.

Appendix A.8 Add Links For References (Both In-Text and External)

Create links for any references in the text, e.g., "see page ###" or "see Bibliography." Links for in-text references are created with the <ptr> element and external references (to other 84000 texts or other web pages) are created with the <ref> element. For further guidelines for creating links with the <ptr> and <ref> elements see Appendix B.4:Cross References and Links.

Appendix A.9 Upload the XML and See How it Looks on the Web Page

  • Go through the text again in web display, making sure everything looks okay.
  • It is helpful at this point to put the web page in “editor mode.” This underlines the linked glossary terms for you. Otherwise, in the regular display, it underlines them but then they will disappear after a few seconds, which will be frustrating when your are checking the links. An additional benefit of editor mode is that all of the collapsed sections of the text (Intro, Translation, Notes, etc...) will be expanded by default, so that you can more easily search for terms in the web display with CTRL-F. To put the page in editor mode, simply add the following text to the end of the URL web address: ?view-mode=editor
  • At this point you should check to see that the glossary is linking to the right terms. In the summary and introduction in particular there may be many instances of a word linking to the glossary when it shouldn’t, for example in the phrase “in terms of…” the word “term” might link to the glossary for the technical meaning of “term”; or to take another example, in the phrase “with respect to…” the word “respect” might link to “respect” as in devotion (these are just two out of many examples). To fix these instances you should add the mode attribute to the <gloss> element in the glossary. If the mode is set to mode="match" (this is the default mode, by the way), you will be able to block strings in the text you don't want to link by marking them with the tag <term type="ignore">. If you change it to mode="marked", it will only link with strings in the text that are tagged with the <term> element (you will need to mark each instance of the term individually in this case). In rare cases you might need to use both modes. For example, in Toh. 127 there are two gloss entries for the term "conceptualization," and there are some instances of this word that should link to the first gloss, some that should link to the second, and some that should link to neither. In this case the first gloss it set to mode="marked" and the second has the default mode="match", then terms that should link to the first are marked with the <term> element, the ones that should link to the second are left untagged, and the terms that should link to neither are marked <term type="ignore">.
  • In these cases you can save yourself some time when choosing between the "marked" or "match" modes. It is good to think about which mode will require the least amount of tags. Usually this will be the default "match" mode, but it varies from case to case.
  • If there are any instances in the web display where there is a term in the glossary that is showing "0 instances in this text" (in the right-hand column of the glossary), you should find out if that term is actually in the text. There may be a spelling error, a diacritic error, or some other reason why it isn't linking to the glossary entry. Sometimes there is a glossary term that really isn't in the text (possibly because it was in the introduction and later removed). If this is the case make a note about it in the final list of questions and issues to address when you have finished the text.
  • There are several subtle points for polishing the final glossary, so we have created a separate Appendix C that explains how the glossary works, along with a few further tips for editing it. Please take a look at Appendix C here.

Appendix A.10 Final Details

A few final things to look out for while going through your final run of the text:

  • Check for extra blank spaces.
  • Double check links and make sure they go to the right places.
  • Make sure links aren't missing. Sometimes if the little "#" is missing or misplaced in the "target" attribute in the <ptr>s then the reference won't appear at all and you will see text like "(see above, .)" without anything coming after it.
  • Do a search for comment tags that may refer to issues that haven't been addressed. To find them you can do a quick search for "<!--".
  • Address any final schema errors. Occasionally, the schema may need to be updated to accommodate a new type of formatting. Or, if a note uses a term in a language that hasn't been used in a published text yet, then that ISO 639-1 code may need to be added to the schema. In either case make a note about this for your final list of questions and issues.
  • Note any formatting or anything else that just looks wrong or awkward.
  • Make note of any grammar or editing errors that you think may have been missed in the copy editing phase. You can also add this to your final list of questions and issues.
  • As you work on the text, make a running list of any problems or issues that you cannot fix yourself and make this into a final list of questions and issues. There are often a lot of things that come up; some of them should be addressed by the lead editor, and some issues may need be updated in the schema or addressed by the technician. This list should be pasted into the Reading Room Revisions spreadsheet, which you can access through this link. There are several sheets within this document. Use the sheet entitled "Texts in Markup" and create a new heading for the text you are working on. Inform the lead editor when you are finished with this list, and we can work on addressing all of these final issues as a team. Read further instructions for how to post issues within the Reading Room Revisions sheet itself, at the top of the "Texts in Markup" page.
  • If there are any schema updates needed, or if there are any parts of this TEI editor's checklist that need to be clarified or updated you can contact Celso to make those updates. You can either assign the task to him on the Reading Room Revisions Sheet or email him at celso.wilkinson@gmail.com.

Appendix B Topics

Appendix B.1 Italics

In a given text, words or phrases may be italicized for different reasons. The need to express both presentation information (that text is italicized) as well as the semantic information about why it is italicized must be addressed. That is why instead of simply using the <hi> element, for example, the voices below form the markup menu for text that needs to be italicized:

  • <distinct> terms, words, or phrases singled out (in any language, but use this only when a "foreign" tag is not applicable).
  • <emph> words or phrases italicized for emphasis or rhetorical effect.
  • <foreign xml:lang=""> foreign words or phrases in any language.
  • <foreign type="term" xml:lang=""> a foreign term or phrase other than a quote or title, such as a term or phrase in parentheses following its translation, or a foreign term or phrase left untranslated.
  • <title xml:lang=""> title of a work (in any language).
  • <foreign xml:lang="__-Ltn"> Wylie or other type of Roman transliteration (excluding European languages, which should not have the "-Ltn" appendage).
  • <foreign type="quote" xml:lang=""> quotations from other texts.
  • <foreign type="mantra" xml:lang=""> mantras or seed syllables.

Note that Tibetan script and Chinese characters should be given the xml:lang value of "bo" and "zh" respectively, while Tibetan, Chinese, and Sanskrit romanized transliteration should have the values of "Bo-Ltn," "Zh-Ltn," and "Sa-Ltn" respectively. For other languages use the list of ISO 639-1 codes to find the appropriate xml:lang value. Most often an Asian language will be translated into the Roman script and, therefore, the first letter of the ISO 639-1 code should be capitalized followed by "-Ltn". Thus a Thai term "th" in Romanized script should be coded "Th-Ltn." If the term is a European language or the native script of that language is used, then use the two letter code as usual, e.g., "fr" (French), "la" (Latin), etc.

For the most part, these tags should be added during the copy editing phase in the 84000 Template.docx. In this phase they will be added as styles in MS Word, but will be transformed into the appropriate tag by our scripts. However, as we can't add a style for every language in the template, the markup editor will need look up and edit the tags for any uncommon languages, which will be marked through the script as xml:lang="Input Language." The markup editor should also keep an eye out for errors, or italicized text that was missed. However, the script should render all unmarked italics with a "<fix>" tag, which will be highlighted as an error by the schema.

Appendix B.2 Divisions

Div elements are used to mark different sections within a text. This is of particular importance as the <head> tag can only follow directly after a "div" marker or another <head> tag. The main sections of the text are marked as follows:

  • <div type="summary"> Wraps the Summary section.
  • <div type="acknowledgement"> Wraps the Acknowledgement section.
  • <div type="prologue"> Wraps the Prologue (if there is one).
  • <div type="preface"> Wraps the Preface (if there is one).
  • <div type="introduction"> Wraps the Introduction.
  • <div type="translation"> Wraps the entire translation.
  • <div type="notes"> Wraps the notes section; this section is needed for displaying abbreviations.
  • <div type="listBibl"> Contains a group of bibl elements, wraps the bibliography.
  • <div type="appendix"> To wrap the appendix of a text, e.g. a Sanskrit Appendix (if there is one).
  • <div type="colophon> Wraps the colophon.

Within those major document units or divisions, there are other sub units, especially chapters or their equivalent. Both chapter and section refer to the same hierarchical level in the XML. Chapters are the type value used in the body of the text when they have been specified as chapters by the translator. Section is used for equivalent level sectioning that has not been called a chapter. Examples for the latter are sectioned bibliographies, where the whole of the bibliography has multiple sections organized by source type. In that case <div type="section"> is used instead of <div type="chapter">. From a structural point of view, however, they are the same.

  • <div type="chapter"> Wraps a chapter that is part of the translation.
  • <div type="section"> Wraps a section of the TEI document.

For example:

<div type="chapter">  <head type="chapter">Chapter 26</head>  <head type="chapterTitle">Turning the Wheel of Dharma</head> <!--...--> </div>

and

<div type="listBibl">  <head type="listBibl">Bibliography</head>  <div type="section">   <head type="section">Tibetan Sources</head> <!--...-->  </div>  <div type="section">   <head type="section">Sanskrit Sources</head> <!--...-->  </div> </div>

Appendix B.3 Outlines

Sometimes the introduction of a text will provide an outline, particularly in the case of a longer or more complicated text. Within the TEI XML these outlines should be constructed using the <list> and <item> elements. For a complex outline with many levels of subsections, the outline itself should be contained in a list, and each section should be contained in an <item> within that list. Then, for each sub section, a new <list> element should be nested within those <item>s, which in turn contains its own subsections with <item> elements, and so forth for as many subsections as necessary. Note that if the <list> is marked up as type="bullet" it will be indented. A good way to render the outline in a clear way is to mark up the first list as type="section" and all subsequent lists as type="bullet"; then the major sections will be separated by vertical spacing and all the subsections will be indented. For an example see the following outline from "The Baskets Display" (Toh 116): The XML markup from this outline in Toh. 116 is shown below.

<list type="section">  <item>   <p tid="642">I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery when      lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha      states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and then      the city of the pretas. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="643">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the          Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama and          describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and praises          him.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="644">II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="645">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells,          visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This          very sūtra sounds in their realm.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>

This will allow the outline to be properly displayed in the 84000 reading room. For more simple outlines that have a one-level list, use the <list> with type="bullet" if the items are one or two sentences long (for an example, see Toh. 11 here), and use type="section" if the items are longer sections of text (see also Toh. 11 here). The "bullet" and "section" types can be used in alternation however they are needed, just note that "section" will have vertical spacing between each item, and "bullet" will be indented.

The <head> element resting within the <list> tag, but outside of the <item> tag can be used to create a bold heading at the top of a list. Alternatively, within an <item> tag a <label> attribute may be used to the same effect. See Toh. 11 again for an example, along with the following XML markup from that same section:

<list type="section">  <item>   <list type="section">    <head tid="3187">I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA</head>    <p tid="33">The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical        understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized.        Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters,        with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10. </p>    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-031-002-47"/>    <item>     <label>Chapters 1 and 2</label>     <p tid="35">In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection          of wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is          the absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative          experiences, all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional          attributes manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including          omniscience. along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of          all things and the finality of existence, these are all attributes with          respect to which a great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment.          Bodhisattvas do perceive such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative          level; in an ultimate sense they consider them to be illusory, in the manner          of a dream and so forth. </p>    </item>    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-031-002-48"/>    <item>     <label>Chapter 3</label>     <p tid="37">Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are          considered as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or          suffering, with self or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or          signless, having or lacking aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void,          afflicted or purified, arising or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as          entities or non-entities. Deluded minds would view these phenomena and          attributes as absolutely existent whereas bodhisattvas should train so as to          understand that they are all non-apprehensible—mere designations and          conceptualizations. </p>    </item> <!--...etc...-->   </list> <!--...etc...-->  </item> <!--...etc...--> </list>

Appendix B.4 Cross References and Links

Milestones:
Cross references in the text that refer to milestones will be added using a <ptr> element with the "target" attribute. The value of the target should be a hashmark ("#") followed by the xml:id value of the milestone that is to be linked. For example:
See <ptr target="#UT22084-060-005-1"/> <!--2.3-->.
The milestone number as it appears on the webpage may be listed as a comment afterwards, but the parser will automatically show the milestone number in the web display. This way even if the milestones shift around it will still display and link to the correct milestone on the web page.

Notes and Bibliography:

Notes and Bibliography entries work in exactly the same way:, for the target attribute, simply use the xml:id value contained in the <note> or <bibl> element that needs to be linked. You can also link to the general bibliography section with the target value "#bibliography." For example:

<note>See <ptr target="#bibliography">bibliography</ptr> </note>

Links to Other Texts or Web Addresses:

If there is a link to a milestone in a different text, rather than using a <ptr>, the <ref> element is used, which should also have a "target" attribute followed by the URL address of the text, followed by a hash tag, followed by the xml:id of the milestone in that other text. For example:

<note index="586" place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-1485"> Unidentified Indian musical instrument. It appears in two lists of instruments in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalita­vistara­sūtra</title> (see <title xml:lang="en">The Play in Full</title>  <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-973">15.39</ref> <!--toh. 95--> and <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-1001">15.67</ref> <!--toh. 95-->) with a stringed instrument preceding and following it, but some recent Tibetan-English dictionaries have “cymbals.”</note>

Links to other websites can be made with the <ref> element in the same manner:

Kyoto: Educational Department of the West Hongwanji, 1924. <ref target="http://web.mit.edu/stclair/www/smaller.html">web.mit.edu</ref>

return to table of contents

Note, if there is an ampersand "&" in the url address this will be read incorrectly in the TEI. The ampersand character itself should be replaced by the ampersand character code "&amp;". The link should now work properly.

Appendix C Guidelines for Glossary
Some Notes About How the Glossary Works:

How Reader Handles Plurals:

A term will be matched if it is followed by s, es, 's, or s' and then a non-word character, e.g. Maitreya, Maitreya's, Maitreyas. (Unfortunately, the general marker for non-word characters is not Sanskrit-aware. It handles Sanskrit diacritic characters as non-word characters. While we have handled most of the related issues in this case it can result in a few mistakes, e.g. Maitreyasāyana).

Use of the <term> Tag to Mark the Same Word Used in Different Ways:

Sometimes we will only want certain instances of a string of text to be marked as a glossary term. For example, perhaps we want the term "appropriate" to be linked to this term when it is used as verb but not when it used as an adjective. Note, that we are no longer using zero-width-non-joiners to resolve this issue. Instead, we now use the "mode" attribute within the <gloss> element.

In the glossary, <gloss> nodes can be given the attributes mode="match|marked." Match mode will highlight any matches in the text except where they have been marked up with <term type="ignore">, e.g.:
parse this <term type="ignore">but not this</term>
Marked mode will only match terms that have been marked up with <term> e.g.
Ignore this <term>but match this</term>.
How Tibetan Is Created from Wylie:

Where a glossary item has a Wylie term but no Tibetan the database will auto-generate the Tibetan. To re-create a Tibetan term simply remove the node, save, and refresh. The Wylie string will also have a trailing space enforced. These will produce the respective syllable separators in the Tibetan. Double underscores in Wylie will be replaced with a single space when output to the reader.

Links to Paragraphs with Instances:

The reader lists links to each paragraph that includes instances of a glossary term.

For Multiple Tibetan and Sanskrit Forms of Spelling for a Single Term:

In some cases a single <gloss> entry may have multiple forms for spelling the Tibetan, the Sanskrit, or both. In this case each spelling of the term can be listed separately in its own <term> element. However, Tibetan should be listed first, followed by the Sanskrit, as in the following example for the term "karnikara" (note that a Tibetan "bo" term is auto-generated after each instance of Tibetan Wylie "Bo-Ltn"):

<gloss type="term"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-5217">  <term>karnikara</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">kar ni </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">ཀར་ནི།</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dong ka </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">དོང་ཀ།</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar ni </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">དཀར་ནི།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">karṇikāra</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">mucilinda</term>  <term type="definition">Pterospermum acerifolium. Other names include bayur, muchakunda,    muchalinda, and dinner-plate tree.</term> </gloss>

Note that in the example above, these spelling variations are supplied by the author but don't actually appear in the translated text. If there are alternative spellings of a term within the text itself, they need to be marked as type="alternative."

Use of Alternatives in the Glossary Entry:

Glossary items can also include <term type="alternative"> nodes to specify other variations in the spelling that should be marked in the text:

<term>Mañjuśrī</term> <term type="alternative">Mañjuśrī­kumāra­bhūta</term>
Further Explanation on the Mode Attribute:

The mode attribute is not required, but when present it can either be "match" or "marked." "Match" is the default (where this attribute is not specified). "Match" will behave in the normal way: the text is scanned for glossary matches and highlighted accordingly.

"Marked," on the other hand, will only consider text strings that have been marked up with <term>. An example for "appropriate" is below:

<!-- Glossary item with mode "marked" --> <item>  <gloss mode="marked" type="term"   xml:id="UT22084-044-003-185">   <term>appropriate</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">len pa </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ལེན་པ་</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ādāna</term>   <term type="definition">See “appropriation.”</term>   <term type="alternative">appropriated</term>  </gloss> </item>
<!-- Only marked up instances in the text will be highlighted --> <p tid="38"> Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, <term>appropriate</term> another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it <term>appropriate</term> different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?” </p>
Some Final Tips for Polishing the Glossary:
  • Sometimes a term will appear in its own definition. In this case it looks a bit silly for the term to link to itself, so it would be best to mark it with <term type="ignore">.
  • If there are references in the definition to a term, such as "see also...", they can be placed into a second <term type="definition"> line, to create some visual lightness in the final webdisplay.
  • If a word is not linking in the webdisplay, here are some common causes for instances not being detected by the parser:
    • Plurals in the middle of strings of words (where the "s" doesn't come at the end).
    • An extra space at the end of the term in the glossary.
    • Sanskrit soft-hypens in the term not matching with the glossary entry.
  • Occasionally you will see a word in the text that is similar to a glossary term but isn't linked because it takes as different form. For instance, "appropriate" is in the glossary, but you see "appropriation" in the text. If you see instances like this you can add an <term type="alternative"> to that <gloss> item, but be sure that you are not then linking to other unwanted instances as well.

return to table of contents

Appendix D Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document

Milestones are applied to the document with the “<milestone unit="chunk"/>” tag. Because the 84000 reading room does not have page numbers, milestones are particularly important for referencing sections or paragraphs in the text.

Milestones should be applied to the text at places where there is a logical/thematic division in the text. Often, milestones can be placed at the beginning of each paragraph of prose. In cases where paragraphs are very short (only one or two sentences) milestones can be placed one for every two or more paragraphs depending on the context, or a particularly short paragraph can share the milestone with that of a larger previous or later paragraph that shares the same “theme.”

To a large degree the editor should use their own judgment: If the milestones are too frequent, then it will become distracting to the reader on the page. If they are too far apart, it will be difficult to cite particular passages of the text. It is helpful to check the display in the reading room after applying milestones to make sure they appear in a convenient way.

Often there will be very short paragraphs used during sections of dialogue. A logical way to organize these sections is to allow one question and answer to be given a single milestone. For example, the following passage could be given one milestone:

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>The Lord then said to the venerable Śāriputra, “Śāriputra, did you see that universe Abhirati, and the Tathāgata Akṣobhya?”</p> <p>Śāriputra replied, “I saw it, Lord! May all living beings come to live in a buddhafield as splendid as that! May all living beings come to have miraculous powers just like those of the noble Licchavi Vimalakīrti!</p>

If either the question or the answer are very short paragraphs (one or two sentences), then they could be appended to the milestone along with their respective question and answer. However, if both the question and answer are long paragraphs in themselves, they should each be given their own milestone. Of course, there will always be unique situations such as questions being answered with another question and so forth. The editor should in general use their own discretion to decide what frequency of milestones would be the most useful and least distracting to the reader. They should to try to be consistent with their usage.

When entering milestones for lines of verse, the editor should apply milestones in a consistent manner, which will typically be one milestone marker between every line group element <lg>. Usually this will be a verse of four lines in English.

For example, see how milestones are applied to the following verses from The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <lg>  <l>Pure are your eyes, broad and beautiful, like the petals of a blue lotus.</l>  <l>Pure is your thought, having discovered the supreme transcendence of all trances.</l>  <l>Immeasurable is the ocean of your virtues, the accumulation of your good deeds.</l>  <l>You affirm the path of peace. O Great Ascetic, obeisance to you!</l> </lg> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <lg>  <l>Leader, bull of men, we behold the revelation of your miracle.</l>  <l>The superb and radiant fields of the sugatas appear before us,</l>  <l>And your extensive spiritual teachings, that lead to immortality </l>  <l>Make themselves heard throughout the whole reach of space.</l> </lg> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <lg>  <l>Dharma-King, you rule with the Dharma your supreme Dharma-kingdom,</l>  <l>And thereby bestow the treasures of the Dharma upon all living beings.</l>  <l>Expert in the deep analysis of things, you teach their ultimate meaning.</l>  <l>Sovereign Lord of Dharma, obeisance to you!</l> </lg>

In another rare case the editor may encounter short sentences used in a debate like dialogue. For example, in this following dialogue found in The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>Mañjuśrī: What is the great compassion of a bodhisattva ?</p> <p>Vimalakīrti: It is the giving of all accumulated roots of virtue to all living beings.</p> <p>Mañjuśrī: What is the great joy of the bodhisattva?</p> <p>Vimalakīrti: It is to be joyful and without regret in giving.</p> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>Mañjuśrī: What is the equanimity of the bodhisattva? </p> <p>Vimalakīrti: It is what benefits both self and others.</p> <p>Mañjuśrī: To what should one resort when terrified by fear of life?</p> <p>Vimalakīrti: Mañjuśrī, a bodhisattva who is terrified by fear of life should resort to the magnanimity of the Buddha.</p>
<milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of virtuous application. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who live by all virtuous principles will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is the magnificence of the conception of the spirit of enlightenment. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who are actually participating in the Mahāyāna will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of generosity. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who give away all their possessions will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of morality. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who follow the path of the ten virtues with positive thoughts will be born in his buddhafield.</p>

Here the editor might place a milestone for each item in the list depending on the length of each paragraph. It might also be appropriate to place the milestones according to logical groupings in the list, for example place one milestone for the four immeasurables, one milestone for the six paramitas, etc. Finally, if the list becomes overburdened by milestones, the editor can add the milestones for every two or four items in the list. In this case it might be worthwhile to check how many items there are in the list then seek a reasonable way to divide it up evenly.

In general, it’s most important to think of milestone placement according to logical connections and divisions within the text itself. Try to group long paragraphs with shorter ones if the shorter paragraph is concluding the ideas of the longer paragraph; try to group items in a list that are related; try to group questions and answers together (where the question gets the milestone and the answer shares the same milestone without getting its own). If there are no logical groupings and many short paragraphs or items in a list, then try to apply consistently according to number (e.g. every two paragraphs, or every four, etc).

If the editor is not sure about the frequency for applying milestones, he or she can refer to some of the other texts in the reader and see how frequently the milestones are used in other texts.

While editing in oXygen, it can be easier to edit milestones while in "author mode" (go to "Author" in the menu bar and click on "Switch to Author Mode." This will show the layout of the text more clearly and you can remove the milestones by double clicking on them and hitting delete.)

return to table of contents

Appendix E Guidelines for Entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit

Note that only editors with a basic understanding of the spelling and sandhi rules of Sanskrit should proceed with this step. You don't need to be an expert in Sanskrit, as most words can be looked up in online references, however, for this step editors will need to have a clear grasp on how the sandhi rules in Sanskrit work. If not please request that another editor with this skill to complete this task.

  • Look for long Sanskrit chains, and add optional soft-hyphens at points where there are chains that are 15+ characters long. Optional soft-hyphens are created with the character code:
    &#173;
    Note that after you save the XML these will look like regular hyphens, but if you move the blinking cursor to the space just before the hyphen you will notice there is a different character code displayed at the bottom of the oXygen screen.
  • The long Sanskrit chains can be found easily by going to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder, then in the XPath/XQuery Builder window type the following code and press the red play button://*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn'] You can save this query for later by clicking on the star and choosing "add to favourites."
  • Be careful when adding the soft hyphens as they should only be placed at certain points in the words where they do not interfere with the Sanskrit rules of sandhi. When adding the soft hyphens please follow the following guidelines:
  • Guidelines for Adding Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit:

    • 1. As we are not using full justification anyway, (a) most Sanskrit words don’t need hyphenation unless they are longer than 5 or 6 syllables, but (b) may be necessary for shorter words especially in text titles on the title page. I therefore tend to place soft hyphens in all of the text titles, in verse passages, in the bibliography entries, and in notes and glossary entries (which require shorter lines in general).

    • 2. Place a soft hyphen (a) only between the words of a compound; (b) even then only when there are no changes brought about by sandhi (because putting a hyphen would logically mean undoing the sandhi, and the hyphens we’re talking about may or may not appear); and (c) avoiding confusing remnants.

      A couple of examples:

      Ratnagotravibhāgottaratantraśāstra would be Ratna-gotra-vibhāgottara-tantra-śāstra. If we divided the 5-syllable sequence in the middle, that would have to undo the sandhi and become -vibhāga-uttara-, which only works in the presence of a hard hyphen. Theoretically we could put a hyphen at vi-bhāga, but that would risk leaving us with -gotravi-, which would be potentially confusing to read.

      The maximum we could hyphenate antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhisaṃdhisamuccedaka would be antānanta-ḍṛṣṭi-vāsanābhi-saṃdhi-sam-ucchedaka, because antānanta and vāsanābhi-saṃdhi would become anta-ananta and vāsana-abhi-saṃdhi. In a case like that, I would also prefer to avoid ending up with antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhi-saṃdhisamuccedaka, because the abhi- really belongs with the saṃdhi; it’s a possible break but is confusing to read.

    • One resource that is helpful for determining the breaks in Sanskrit chains in the online Cologne Sanskrit Dictionary. This one is really helpful because it has a drop down menu of similarly spelled words when you hit the enter key, however, I think this only works when you use the Kyoto-Harvard Transliteration scheme "KH." You might try the other ones but I found that this is the only one that gave the drop down list for me. Then when you find a big word in the dictionary in the definition entry you will see * whenever there is sandhi, though this isn't 100% reliable. Sometimes it is missing for some reason, so be careful if the spelling looks weird.
    • In certain cases there may be long 15+ Sanskrit chains that cannot be broken due to the sandhi, or long Sanskrit compounds whose pieces cannot be easily determined with online resources. If this is the case make a list of problematic instances to note for the leading editors, and also check these instances to see if the pose any major difficultly for the web display. These instances are rare, but they do come up now and then.
    • It is acceptable to add an optional hyphen at the end of "mahā-" as in "mahā-yāna" even though technically the long ā would be lost, as this is a well known word and unlikely to be misread.
    • Note that when you add the optional hyphens to a glossary item where the translation uses the Sanskrit (This will mainly be in the “Persons” and “Places” section of the glossary) the hyphens will have to match all those instances within the body of the text or they will not link to the glossary term, so it is best to start from the glossary and work your way backwards. For all of these person and place terms do a search and replace so that the hyphens match in all the instances of that term (be cautious when doing large search-and-replaces that you don’t make any unintended changes).

return to table of contents
